reviewText: It is hard to sum up One Way Heroics into just a few words, so let me give you a couple paragraphs. (If you're the sort that likes to go tl;dr" then just scroll to the bottom
recommended: then why are you even reading reviews to begin with?)\n\nI picked this game up for <$0.60 when it was sale during the summer. I have to say
hoursPlayed: those were the best $0.60 I have ever spent. One Way Heroics doesn't appeal to you with stunning graphics
voteText: rich storytelling
helpfulPercent: or intricate gameplay. Instead
votesHelpful: it is more retro gaming
votesTotal: silly short tales
votesFunny: and an easy to pick-up set of controls. Now you might be wondering
commentsCount: why would I want something like that? Arguably everything but simplicity of the controls could be considered negative or at least niche.  One Way Heroics doesn't offer high spec gaming while emptying your wallet - what you're buying is meaningless fun and entertainment.\n\nWhen I first opened this game and started an adventure
column16: I found myself with my silly little 2D character talking to a "Naughty King Victor" about the darkness at the left of my screen that would attempt to eat me until I killed the Demon Lord. Yes
column17: clearly the storyline could use some work
column18: but as I struggled to kill weak mobs and then stronger demons I found myself falling for this game. Everything was fairly straightforward and the desire to complete achievements
column19: "save the world
column20:
and become a true hero compels you to play over and over again. It doesn't take several hours to do a run through like a quest in some RPG, just 30 minutes or so if you're short on time. Yet, you can play longer sessions that go for tens of hours depending completely on what you want to do and how much time you have - and those hours? They were some fun hours.

I won't try to tell you that you'll be so entranced with One Way Heroics that you'll spend thousands of hours playing it - you probably won't. But it's easy to lose 10, 20, maybe even 100 hours of your life having fun by sending your hero towards the right of your screen. Was that worth my 60 cents while it was on sale? Definitely. Is it worth the full $3.49? Absolutely. Most of us play games to have fun - and One Way Heroics delivers.

tl;dr?

If you're a hardcore gamer looking for a game with brilliant graphics and intricate/competitive gameplay to drop thousands of hours on, I think you're better off somewhere else.
If you're someone looking to spend 10-100 hours having fun in your spare time? Buy One Way Heroics.

reviewText: One of the more overlooked games on Steam (probably because it was made in Wolf RPG Editor), this game was actually made by the creator of Wolf RPG Editor. In this game, you have to battle against the screen scrolling basically. If you get scrolled off the screen, you die. There are lots of interesting RPG elements at play here, such as different classes, leveling, skills, weapons, partners, and more. You can also save some items from your failed runs to use for the next run. The game is procedurally generated, and you can play worlds other people played by entering their world's seed. The game will also show you who was/is online on the same map you are. There are daily maps to explore and this game has a ton of depth you might not expect just looking at it. The expanded version is out on Playism and coming to Steam in the near future, but this version is well worth playing on its own.

reviewText:
Video Review:

http://youtu.be/B7IW8tWpZB8

I put quite a few hours in on the game before it released on steam.

The game feels quite smooth so it took my brain some time to process the fact that this is a turn based game and play accordingly.  Once I figured it out though, I really enjoyed myself.  There are lots of unlockable classes, map modes, and difficulty levels.  Plus the world is randomly generated so the game can be different every time.  Since character stats and a limited number of items/weapons carry over between play throughs the game has good replay value and individual save slots add even more.

Initially I didn't like the darkness/forced scrolling mechanic but it grew on me as I played.  With the darkness quickly following you, every action matters in combat and dungeon exploration so even though the game won’t move without you, there isn't much chance to catch your breath in these situations.  There is a genuine fear of trying to open a chest only to get trapped by the darkness that nicely complements the regular fear of death by monster.  The game is fun so despite bland visuals, if you watch game play with this information and it seems interesting or you enjoy rouge like games, then for well under $5 I can recommend Once Way Heroics.

reviewText:
One Way Heroics is like potato chips: you eat one, and you can't help but go for another.

For those moments where a player wants to pop open an RPG, but doesn't quite want to start a 40 hour time investment, OWH is perfect; simple combat, roguelike gameplay, and varied challenge levels depending on one's mood. Whether for a 20 minute stroll or an epic 2-hour odyssey with perma-death waiting around every corner, this game aims to suit itself to multiple tastes.

Finishing a game, whether winning or losing, awards points used to boost one's future playthroughs (with wins awarding more). Whether it be unlocking new perks or opening new slots in the Dimensional Vault to transfer items from one playthrough to the next, every run feels like it progresses the player. That being said, while there are technically save areas, losing concludes the run and records the player's performance right there - no going back to try and get more points, but it will allow you to conclude a run 'just for funsies'. Maniac Mode, the game's 'hardcore' setting also prevents players from importing items from previous games, though depositing new items is still possible. Save points and dimensional vaults make the game friendly for casual runs, but the true hero wins on Maniac Mode with no takesies backsies (the greatest scores are only counted upon no deaths).

More than that, the game is also surprisingly colorful. Dialogue and narrative is sparse, but sweet and entertaining. Furthermore, there are hidden secrets everywhere: the various characters you meet may have hidden dialogue, items may have unexpected purposes, and the non-restrictive nature of weapons gives a lot of freedom in designing 'builds'. There are even secret ways to win - it is recommended you do not go in with a guide, and simple explore yourself, as reading the wiki ruins a lot of the surprises this game has to offer (don't even look up those secret ways to win).

This reviewer's only criticism is that, after clocking a couple dozen hours, I'm ready for more! The weapons do resemble each other a bit too much, there's a hard limit on the available spells/abilities, dungeons resemble each other, and the charming character dialogues do eventually run dry.

For $3.50, this game was absolutely and totally worth it. It's creative, it's original, it's got high replayability, it suits people looking for various challenge levels, and it deserves to be recognized for what it is: a small but great roguelike RPG.

reviewText:
Being a big fan of Anime, turn based RPG's and rogue-like games, I was very curious with One Way Heroics, having an accessible price, I decided to risk buying it and check it out, truth be told I would never thought I'd love this game so much as I do, it completely caught me by surprise.

The mechanics are quite simple, you're forced to go eastwards in an 8 character string world (that is randomly generated each play-through) in order to avoid a mysterious mist that is covering the planet.

Each decision you take being a dialogue option, attacking, defending, healing, equipping and so on, will be counted as a turn, each turn you do the mist will also do his in parallel so you'll have to make sure to not fall behind or your play-through will be over, so you'll have to have special attention to which decisions or paths you should take, sometimes you'll feel compelled to explore a dungeon and find new items but the mist can prove to be too risky since you'll always have that constant threat looming next to you.

You have different ways of ending one play-through depending of the difficulty and the game mode you're playing, you can achieve victory by killing the demon king, by reaching the end of the world, by killing a secret boss and so on, in order to spice it up the developers decided to make some random events, cities and quests to make the game more interesting and more unique in each play-through.

The game UI is quite simple and it does well its job, the game soundtracks are fun and memorable but they can get a bit repetitive after a while, the art style ain't phenomenal by any means but overall it has an interesting and unique presentation to it.

The game is very affordable and full of content, it has great replay value, so I'd like to recommend to all of you who is thinking about getting this underrated gem, you'll love it!

reviewText:
Sold everything I had to a poor merchant for silvers, made him get mauled by a bear, took the stuff he dropped, walked away with 50,000 silvers and all my stuff and extra, rinsed and repeated with every town I come upon. Got 999.999 silvers and became the richest man in the world where money doesn't matter anymore because everyone is dying. put on a bracelet that bloody merchant lying on the ground had, sacrificing half my stats but getting 3x experience, after 10 days I rose to level 649 and became an all powerful God. One-hit killed everyone I came across by punching it in the face. True story.

Actual Review of the Game:
Totally worth the price when it goes on sale like the Steam Summer Sale and the Winter Exploration Sale where it gets to less than a buck. There's 8 classes (only a couple in the beginning), but 24 sprites to choose fun. The worlds are randomly generated and filled with a lot of content that take a long time to go through, finding almost a new thing everytime. After a long time, my brother and I went through every NPC, companion, items, and weapons you could go through, but it never got boring because it's so different (yet the same) every time! I just recently got the DLC One Way Heroics Plus and it has about 3x the content now comparing it to the original, much more aesthetics and features that got me into it again. The music that is seen throughout the different biomes, towns, and bosses is also really good enough that I put them on my phone because you can find them online for free. Its just awesome overall.

I r8 8/8 m8 no h8, it gr8

I use Zenura Weave, sacrificing my clothing for power.
I go into a town and people judged me, the one that's saving them all, for not wearing anything.
I run into the Demon Lord, who is a lonely reject hellbent on killing everyone in the world.
Since we both weren't accepted, we ultimately joined forces and ran across the entire world together, allowing everyone of those townsfolk to suffer from the darkness.

All in all, this game is a beautiful story about discrimination, friendship, streaking, punching cute animals, and acceptance.

reviewText:
So, after finally clearing the game and seeing 95% of what it has to offer, I figured I could give my two cents to people considering wether to buy this game.
Simple version? Buy it. Longer version:

Plot

The setting itself is quite simple. You are the hero, saving the world from darkness that's devouring everything. And to do that you have to kill Demon Lord, who's somewhere over there ------>
That's basically it, but there is so much more, if you care to search for it. Game is filled with alternative endings, hidden classes, party members... Well, you get the point. It actually makes me really sad that only 4,6% of players have invested time to complete the game in some other way, than beating the Demon Lord, as they are missing out on great plot, that's just hidden within seemingly generic RPG storyline.

Gameplay

As you embark to find the Demon Lord somewhere over that ------> way in randomly generated world, the said darkness is chasing you, destroying villages, killing the monsters and, most important of all, keeping you from stopping.  On your way you'll encounter multitude of different terrain types, villages, dungeons, enemies, merchants, friends, (friendly) ghosts of other players and so on. The further you go, the harder game becomes.
Combat is very much in retro RPG style. You act ---> your party members act ----> enemies act. Extra agility can get you (or enemies) multiple moves in a row. There are status ailments, buffs, critical hits and plenty other things involved as well.

Difficulty

The game lets you pick the difficulty setting from Walk in a park, Afternoon Stroll, Grueling Campaign or Inhumane odysseu, but even the Walk in a park isn't exactly a cakewalk for newcomer, while Inhumane Odysseu often catches even experienced players by surprise. You also choose your class, perks, and wether you'd like to start with some items from your previous misadventures, so game lets you have very much control over the level of difficulty.

Overall

I enjoyed this game immensely. When i got it for around 0,60€, I felt like I was robbing the developer, because this game is a rare gem that has great potential. So I was just happy to pay the 5-ish € for the new DLC, as I felt I had finally paid him back.
The game is addictive (albeit a bit repetitive), and easily triggers the ONE MORE RUN" -feeling
date: that made me waste many evenings while trying to overcome hardest ordeals the game had to throw at me."

reviewText:
So, I bought this game a long time ago thinking it was going to be a game where I ran in one direction trying to stay alive.

I was not disappointed in the slightest.

One-way Heroics offers some of the dumbest, funniest, and rediculous gameplay I have ever seen from a rouge-like game.

*Slight spoilers below, you have been warned*

-Hey, I know you're new, but you're supposed to save the world from the left side of the screen since this is sidescrolling and all, and for some reason the left side of the screen is eating everything. GOOD LUCK!

So begins your slow and painful descent into hell.

At the 1st gate of hell you pick your class, name, and perks (assuming you even have any). At first you'll wonder why you only get two classes, and thats because without any foundation the others will either be ♥♥♥♥ easy to play (IM LOOKING AT YOU PIRATE <3) or even harder to get going than your beginner classes (coughForceUsercough).

At the 2nd circle of hell you wander around on Walk in the Park" mode (easy mode) and you get the gist of the game....while simultaneously wondering why the fabled final boss meets you at a predetermined point or why they even want to kill you (I still dont remember signing up for this ***....Was I Voluntold?). You also realize multiplayer is a lie

reviewText:
To be perfectly honest, I didn't expect that much for the $3.50 full price of the game.  I was pleasantly surprised.  The number of hours of gameplay to price has proven to be a solid purchase.

I do not wish to oversell.  This is a solid game.  It has both pros and cons.  However, at this price point, it's a very high return on price.

The Pros are that it's a 2d sidescrolling, roguelike, fantasy style game that contains elements of progression post rogue-like death.  The unique aspect of the game is that the world is constantly scrolling to the right, and that if the hero is trapped on the far left of the screen, it's game over.  The game offers a few classes, with more unlocked as you continue to play through, and the ability to carry forward items (how many items can be expanded as well).  It's a typical 2d fantasy style throwback game.

The Cons of this game is the seemingly random difficulty at times.  Experiencing impossible creatures right outside the starting castle, and random event demons that you can't avoid.  This can be painful if you're trying to clear with a particular class and have dedicated some game clearing items towards your hero!  As mentioned in other reviews, there's also random map loading, which can hurt continuity of the game, but is overall relatively minor.

With all of this in mind, I believe buyers will experience a good playtime/cost ratio with this game.

reviewText:
By this point, we all know what a roguelike is, even if the exact distinctions have become muddled. Perhaps many of you play roguelikes fanatically. I am not talking games like Binding of Isaac or FTL. I am talking ADOM, Nethack, Dungeon Crawl, those sorts.

Those of you who do play those games may feel at times that their greatest strengths, their vast complexity and length, can often become overbearing and intimidating. By the end of any roguelike, the game becomes exhaustive. You've been at that game for days just for that one playthrough. And how many times did you have to die just to learn every special situation, and figure out every monster along the way to victory? These games require a lot of cognitive overhead and rote memorization.



Doesn't it seem counterintuitive that I write a gripe about roguelikes in a recommendation for a roguelike? Yes, sure, but this is exactly what One Way Heroics tries to shy away from. It is a true roguelike, but it shies away from the issues I stated before. It plays fast and simple. You could expect to complete a full game within a few hours, and it provides enough of a challenge that it isn't a pushover for it. The wall of death to your left also rids you of the tedium of stashes and grinding.

Your perspective of the game may be different from mine, but this is the most important aspect to me. This is how I sum up the game and why I play it.

I play roguelikes for their nuanced and complex gameplay.
I play One Way Heroics for its simplicity and short length per playthrough.

reviewText:
Fairy-tale with references to JRPG & Dragon Quest in particular.

This is 'indie' at it's finest-not for the sake of following someone's example,or lack of artistic skills.It is (nearly) perfect as it is

Developer of this little gem is sure passionate about his creation,and it shows.
Music is what changes this from simple roguelike into captivating magical journey.Even through all of it is free sound tracks from the net-every piece fits perfectly into the game.Art,humour,lots of secrets-also add to the charm.

Even failing and failing and failing again,I,personally never felt irritated or tired.It's magic,I tell you.It's like one NeverEnding Story.

I may be a hopeless romantic and even more hopeless nerd,but really,this game needs no analysis nor ratings.It's just very bright,simple(for a roguelike,that is)and fun.What else do you need from games?

reviewText: Alright listen closely. This game is really, REALLY good. Especially for it's price! It's literally a steal! You may be thinking from the screenshots Oh no. Another RPG Maker game." reviewText: I bought One Way Heroics due to the plethora of positive reviews I saw...and because it was .69 cents in the steam summer sale. ;D However, I must say it has been the BEST .69 cents I have ever spent. I have put in over 10 hours of addictive gameplay, wondrous music, and hilarious and/or close-call moments in less than a week; all of which is wrapped up into one simple--but nothing less than amazing--game.\n\nI can not emphasize enough how much I recommend that others get this game. It is not difficult to play, but can be hard to master, especially on harder difficulties. Finally, it is user-friendly and truly allows the player to challenge themselves or take it easy (whatever they feel like at the time they play). Great for all ages as long as they like the genres and style of gameplay this game has to offer.

reviewText:
085/100

My favorite Rogue-Like of 2014

The game is very simple but very fun. You play an adventurer because excuse plot and you need to save the world, just like in Half-Life 3.
Darkness is coming from the left and so the only thing you can do is go right.

It's a 2D Final Fantasy 13 in that sense but the graphics and plot development here is waaay better.
Square Enix really needs to take lessons from Sony and make another Final Fantasy X Sonic game.

Pick up loot, kill wild monsters, avoid getting trapped against walls or else it will be game over.
If you don't play rogue games often however expect to die, a lot! Hunger will cripple you, monsters will one shot kill you, walls and other obstacles will always seem to get in the way at the worst possible time, and thieves will spawn while you are already holding on for dear life.

Despite the above however the game is not about cheap deaths! This is refreshing because Rogue like games usually go the 'uber hard' route by killing you for trivial stuff. You know the kind, you didn't drink enough water so died. You didn't see the hidden pit of instant death so you fell in it and died. This game has none of those, if you died, it was your fault and you can learn something from every death. This means the game is more about learning than it is about gruelling difficulty which is what makes it so much fun.

Enjoy the game and watch out for those treasure chests in dungeons, they'll get you killed.

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

reviewText:
Rating 9/10

What is it?

This is a turn based rogue game that has an isometric perspective. You have to constantly keep moving to the right because a darkness keeps creeping in from the left.

The Good

+ 8 Classes to fit your play style. Knight, sword master, hunter etc.  Obviously each one has their own unique strengths and weakness  along with their own stat growth rate.

+ Different modes offer players interesting new dynamics to the world. I.e Better weapons but harder enemies

+Different levels of difficulty. The easiest difficulty level stops at a certain distance, however the later difficulties can be much longer.

+ Lots of secrets to find out, giving the game a lot more depth than it appears to

+ Randomized Levels

The Bad

- The game can be frustrating, especially if you get a bad world generated.


Conclusion

This game is surprisingly addicting. At first it doesn't look like much but the more you play it the more it grows on you. You quickly realize that strategy is involved depending on the class your playing. The fact that you are forced to keep moving means you are going to have to make some tough decisions. Given the price point, this is probably one of the better deals you will find.

reviewText:
One Way Heroics is a decidedly different and refreshing take on the rogue genre. Simply put, every decision you make causes the world to end just a little bit more. An existence-destroying void is following you, and the only solution is to constantly push to the right. You'll have to make detours, whether it's shopping for supplies, exploring for dungeons, or going after some great treasure.

As with most other Rogue titles, death is permanent...and expected. Your first game might last several minutes, your second might last a few seconds. Dying tends to result in rewards such as new perks, classes, and the ability to store useful items in a vault for future games. This is all dependent on your hero points, a score received at the end of the game. Surviving as long as possible is just one of many ways to accrue points. The character classes and perks offer a good bit of variety in how you approach the game. There are other awards depending on your in-game actions, so it's always worth trying new things and exploring as much as that rapidly expanding void will allow.

Adding to the replay value is the infinite number of randomly-generated worlds. One Way Heroics has numerous online functions, so it's possible for multiple players to explore the same world. While playing, you'll see the status of other heroes and get a sense of their trials and tribulations. When they die, their cause of death will be displayed. You might even happen upon their remains, and score a nice item for yourself. Despite the game's cheap price, it's still receiving great support by the developer. In fact as of this writing there was an update issued just yesterday. Multiple difficulty settings further add to the replay value.

Really though, the main reason I recommend this game is because staying from the void is such a valuable design-decision. Typical rogue games, with their insistence on dark dungeons, tend to bore me. One Way Heroics is very focused, it's linear, but it retains all of the depth that is consistent with the genre. Every decision in the game carries weight, since the void is never far behind. I never get the sense that I'm just meandering around a dungeon looking for a key or a sword or a set of stairs. Every step is essentially proof of life, and it feels like very real progress(though death remains a very real setback).

All in all, One Way Heroics is an unexpected surprise. I look forward to putting more time into it.

reviewText:
I'm no expert on roguelikes. But this game at base price costs about as much as a cup of coffee from a mid-market coffee chain. I've played it for twenty hours, and it still feels like I'm scratching the surface; after each run, I feel like I learned something about how the game works, about what it wants from me and how to succeed. It's a good feeling. The game is fair but challenging, and for those of us for whom that isn't enough, offers a highly modular difficulty system (base difficulty plus class plus perks, all of different usefulness) to challenge yourself with. There's incremental progress and upgrades to unlock if you'd rather have a barometer of progress other than your own growing skill at the game, which is difficult to quantify, but grinding for these things isn't really an issue -- classes and perks are pretty cheap, at least for the useful ones, and everything else is bonus stuff.

If you buy the expansion, you're basically getting a game that has double or triple the content of the base game, and also includes a whole bunch of quality of life UI upgrades and balance changes. A lot of the things added are very simple and unobtrusive but satisfying -- things like turning to face the enemies automatically, a little screen to track all of the things you've achieved as each class, more dimensions to facilitate the psuedo-multiplayer. Other additions are bigger -- new classes, new allies, new npcs, new bosses and objectives and missions. While the price of the dlc is triple that of the base game, it's absolutely worth it -- even more so if you can get it on sale. The hours of gameplay/$ ratio is excellent.

It's also in the class of games that are easy to play while doing something else, like holding a skype conversation or queuing for a match in some other game. It takes very little processor power, deals with tab switching quite agreeably, and time stops while you aren't moving.

All in all, I think it's a great way to spend an hour or two between doing other things, and ends up being quite moreish once you've wrapped your head around the basic steps to survival. Then, it's all about the rng and your own wits. Recommended.

reviewText:
A Great Time killing game, hold on Solitare, Chip's Challenge, or whatever you play to kill time, here's ONE WAY HEROICS
So after playing this game for a good little bit, I have found that this game could easily be one of those games that you could play to kill time, ALOT of time.

One of my friends sent me the game and expansion as a gift through Steam, and I tell you what, It's quite an amazing game especially for use old heads that like our RPGs and video games in general with a more retro feel to them. The graphics, by today's standards, aren't the super realistic HD sculptures that a lot of people have come to expect from video games. Instead, the graphics are more of a 16-bit sprites with beautiful choices of color palettes throughout the game. It is very easy to tell when you traverse through different environments, desolate deserts, cold artic tundra, lush beautiful forests and plains. The guards, townsfolk, and inhabitants of the world are just as carefully designed and all look unique.

Probably one of the biggest things that makes this game so great is the gameplay. Imagine a Japanese Style Action RPG with a lot of Rogue like aspects that do nothing, but add to replay value of the game. Everything can be randomized, and like most Rogue Likes perma death is a real thing. About the only thing that you can save, aside from the game, is your character's inventory, or rather a select few items to continue playing with. You get a super awesome sword that when roots your enemies and burns them to death, and you don't really want to let it go? Well there's something called a deminisonal vault that you can use to keep that sword through multiple playthroughs.

Speaking of that deminisonal vault, the way you get it, and use it is through things called Hero Points. You acquire Hero Points by either completing a full run of the game, or dying. If you die, by some random Dragon Knight in a structure you were checking for loot, drowning in water, or trying to climb to the point of exhaustion and just collapsing. There's also one other very unique way of dying. In this game, you visit a town and you can't revist it, you can't go back the way you came at all. This is because the Dark Lord (boss of the game) is spreading darkness throughout the realm, you touch the darkness and you die. Well the screen scrolls to the right, just like an old school platformer, but instead of being able to go back you can't because of the darkness, if you try, you die. This adds for a significant amount of challenge, you can easily get stuck in areas of the game because of mountains, walls, or whatever other obstacle that impedes your travel, and the darkness catches up and you die. Actually, every action you take, wether it's attacking an enemy, moving, using an item, casting a spell, or whatever moves the darkness closer towards you.

The Plot is a throw a way plot you are X hero out to slay the Dark Lord and stop the spread of the darkness throughout the world. There's other campaigns that you can do that are fixed maps that have their own story as well, but it follows the same formula.

Probably one of the coolest things about the game is Character Creation. At the beginning of the game you start with two classes, a Swordmaster Class and a Knight Class. You can chose what your sprite looks like, and also give your character perks to help with his stats, or whatever skills you have for the class. You start with three perk slots, but as you play you can unlock up to five perks. This alone gives the game that massive replay value, just to see how every other class works, in a completely different world every single time.

As you play through the game, and earn Hero Points,  you also gain new classes to run through the game with, each class, plays very differently from the other. You unlock these classes by either spending those Hero Points you've been hoarding, or by completing specific tasks in game. Aside from the Deminsional Vault, and new Classes, the Hero Points also unlock new perks for character creation.

For us retro gaming fans, especially those who are fans of RPGs that came out before everything looked pretty" and realistic
date: this game is a must own. This will probably end up replacing solitare for those people."

reviewText:
One way to get the most out of life is to look upon it as an adventure. -William Feather*I would like to give a special thanks to Earl[33rd] for proof-reading this review and for initially presenting this title to me.
Developed by Indie studio Smoking WOLF and released on February 28, 2014, One Way Heroics (OWH) is a two-dimensional procedurally-generated roguelike in which an increasing threat of dark essence jeopardizes every individual in the expanse. You play as a custom character on a trek to defeat the Demon Lord, a powerful entity that imperils the world with the motivation toward total destruction. Before meeting the tendrils of corruption, the player must endure a certain distance-decided when choosing the various game settings-while destroying hostile creatures.
Here are a few items of interest within OWH:

Gameplay - Aside from other roguelikes, this title’s complexity is derived from its tactical display rather than gameplay, as One Way Heroics utilizes a turn-based approach to combat and item usage. Each in-game action made by the hero utilizes said turns, which advances the daunting foe. The term ‘turn-based strategy’ does not entirely cover this game’s spectrum, however, as every action, whether it be equipping a new weapon or item, or consuming a potion to gain back energy, summons evil one turn closer to the player’s character. Adding to the ominous theme, the darkness swallows the lands you have passed through, and the notification of non-player character deaths can be heard as they disappear into mist. Controls are rather simple on both keyboard and controller, but can be adjusted in the case that they feel awkward. Equipment can be modified within the menus to alter the method of play by adding boons to weapons and armor, but, as stated, this increases danger; these items are gained either as loot from defeated enemies or may be distributed throughout the map. With a high enough Charisma score, the player may also gain discounts from various shops and recruit non-player individuals to the party that will assist in combatting foes and leveling up.

Character Creation & Upgrades - Characters comprise of several customizable components, such as name, class, avatar, and perk and statistical preferences chosen by the player; perks may also grant players companions or other game modifications such as quicker swimming or improved unarmed damage. These adjustments allow the player to modify how they would like to play according to the class. Additional equipment may alter damage totals to enemies or reduce them toward the player’s character. Levelling up in OWH operates in a similar way to other titles, as it improves the character’s base statistics depending on which class was chosen.

Unlockables - Depending on how far the player’s character progresses in the campaign, a number of Hero Points are rewarded to the player to purchase game augments. These modifications increase the amount of content usable by the player, such as said hero classes, perks-with selections for both combat and other skills-, and expanding what’s known as the Dimensional Vault: an item-storage system in which adventurers may donate a number of items from preceding generations to the next living hero. This expands play so that the entire game is not just an uphill battle with no reward when so close to the resolve, but rather contains encouragement toward progression.

TL:DR - One Way Heroics is a fun, simple, and rewarding title with incentive to advance toward the Demon Lord time and time again. There is a great amount of challenge involved in this title, but does not evoke frustration due to its Hero Point system. Though the accolade of defeating the ultimate evil may not be reached every time, the journey is a fantastic ride filled with choice, vicious battle, and sacrifice. I highly recommend this title to anyone who enjoys roguelikes and simple roleplaying mechanics. This game has a great deal of replayability, and I hope you enjoy upon purchase. Thanks for reading.

Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews.

reviewText: Ive sunk many hours into this game when i grabbed it off Playism a few months ago. At first it seems like the mechanics are rather simple, but you will find a surprising amount of depth and strategy will go into completing your longer journeys. Between balancing your health, stamina, and always being wary of the black creeping death behind you. If you are a fan of random generation or a fan of RPGs I highly recommend this game. With unlockable classes to keep you coming back for more, and an online leaderboard of sorts (you can play a mode where it tracks your distance traveled along with everyone else playing that mode in realtime) theres a lot of reasons to put a good amount of time into this title.

reviewText:
One Way Heroics is a series of infinite rougelike adventures. In the game you play as various classes and as you get farther in randomized worlds you can unlock new classes to play in future runs.

The screen constantly scrolls to the left and if you do not move to the right you are killed instantly. As you run to the right you kill enemies to level up while picking up better gear. Once in a while you encounter a town where you can spend money on new items or food, and sometimes you encounter dungeons with great loot.

An interesting mechanic that helps the game last longer are the perks you can unlock with points you get after an adventure is complete. Before you start a game you can select up to 5 perks (after you unlock the 5 slots) that can help you on your run and you can even carry over items you've obtained to use later.

Overall One Way Heroics is worth the $2.00 asking price and is deserving of any casual-hardcore gamer.

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game? Yes. Do I want more people to buy it both before and after the sale, which by the way is a ridiculously small price to pay for such a deep and interesting game? Absolutely 100% yes. I first saw this game on Greenlight a few months back, and I honestly thought it looked like crap. Seeing that it went on sale for eighty-seven cents, I figured I'd sell a few cards off and buy it, which turned out to be probably the best idea I've had throughout the whole summer sale.

I really honestly love roguelikes, and this is about as good as it gets for me. Tough enemies? Check. General time constraints? You bet. Omnipresent instant-death wall that constantly follows you and kills the NPCs you pass by? Oh, yes. There's so much to love about this game, and that's just with the gameplay. The story is honestly one of the best I've seen in a game so seemingly small and shallow (though, that was only on the surface). What starts as a quest to kill a Demon Lord over and over turns into so much more, but I won't spoil anything here. There's so much rich backstory to get around to, and close to (or I think exactly?) a dozen endings to unlock. The endings may be short, but they're very, very sweet. The wordplay is a bit awkward, at times, but most of the endings managed to evoke the emotions I feel they were meant to.

This game caught me so far off-guard, that I ended up 100%ing it, getting every epilogue, and every achievement, in just twenty-two hours of gameplay. That may not seem like much, but I went super hard and no-life'd it. Not because I wanted to get it done as quickly as possible, but because I wanted to challenge myself to completely finishing it in as little time as I could. Would I do it all again, casually? Yes, and I plan to play it now and then when I get bored, trying new character builds and strategies, and getting the highest heroics scores I can manage.

I'd absolutely recommend this game, again. Buy it. It's cheap (as of writing this review) AND it's cheap in general, at only $3.50. Buy it. You (probably) won't regret it. If you like roguelikes, that is. If you don't care for dying lots and in lots of sometimes funny or dumb ways, then don't buy it. I love this game.

reviewText: This game has to rank amongst one of my top most favorite rogue-like RPGS. With the first difficulty already being hard and the other difficulties and scenarios much harder than the previous one, this game makes you carefully plan your decisions (through movements, skills, choosing appropiate stats, and watching your three bars closely) in order to even get close to killing the final boss. All of the classes have a completely different playstyle (besides that most of them require you to use basic attacks to damage) to even get past the 100m mark. And although you start fresh everytime you begin a new character, the game rewards you by allowing you to keep a limit of items from past runs to aid your next. All of these elements combine to create a satisfacting experience that can be enjoyed by any RPG player and can consume time faster than you consume a bucket of KFC chicken. The soundtrack is worth a mention as well, fitting and worthy of rocking your head to the beat at the speed of the tempo. I would highly recommend this game to all RPG fans looking for a fair amount of difficulty, and recommend all casual players to give it a go as well. It's more than well worth its price of $3.49, so try this amazing masterpiece of a turn-based slightly pixelated RPG.

reviewText:
It's a roguelike with pressure ever looming to the left side of the screen, in the form of a shadow engulfing the world. You must travel to the east, hopefully getting stronger along the way, because to the far east, the Demon Lord, who summoned the darkness, awaits.

Key features:
- JRPG look and feel
- No location transition; everything happens on the overworld map
- Shadow pressing you to move on vs stick around longer to explore more of this town/dungeon
- Turn-based
- JRPG style menu system
- Running non-stop, your hero still require sustenance
- Items have limited durability
- With each death (or victory) you gain hero points, which can be used to purchase more options (and thus more freedom) in future games
- Item vault to transfer items to your next characters. Item vault size is expanded by using hero points
- Unlockable classes
- Unlockable perks
- Randomly generated world with a short text-based random seed
- Many features in the world which you can explore. (I found some high-end merchants hidden inside a mountain once. Was too slow to get back out).
- You can replay a world by entering the seed
- Fast paced. You can easily win a game in one sitting
- Online events everyday. There are worlds with special rules which you can play in
- Multiple difficulty levels can be unlocked
- Great attention to details that will make you smile
- Steam cards and achievements

This $2.69 will be the best $2.69 you've ever spent.

reviewText: I paid 86 cents for this on sale, and it's one of the best damn games I've played all year. The concept is clever, and the execution is basically flawless. OWH has more polish and apparent effort put in than a lot of games from big studios. You can pick it up and play without too much investment, but there's more depth than is initially obvious. Repeat plays are encouraged with daily worlds, higher unlockable difficulties, new classes/perks, and lots of secrets and extra endgame content. The graphics, music and translation/humor are also spot on. UUUUUUGH JUST BUY IT

reviewText:
One Way Heroics plays like your typical mystery dungeon game, but this time, it's a bit different. Your dungeon is a randomly generated overworld that scrolls in one direction, dotted with enemies, dungeons, towns, and treasure. What I love most about the game is that at the conclusion of a runthrough, you're rated based on your actions and progress which in turn rewards you with points used to unlock new classes, new perks, or expand our dimensional vault(a storage that allows you to bring over items from a previous gameplay).

The game is a great price, only three dollars and it has alot of replay value. Even if you beat normal and hard modes, there are other modes that are updated and added into the mix every so often that challenges you with a new way to play.

If you enjoy Japanese RPG, or mystery dungeons(Shiren the Wanderer, Izuna: The Unemployed Ninja, Pokemon Mystery Dungeon) you have got to get this game, especially since it's super cheap! No reason why anyone shouldn't have it!

reviewText:
I owned this through Desura and since then have streamed over a hundred hours of OWH on my twitch channel. Just buy it, I am not joking; any gamer should be able to appreciate it. One Way Heroics looks really simple and shallow on the surface but it is a gem that wont break the bank! Why should you buy this game?

*Multiple classes, fully customizable with feats and items from your vault and shops.
*Near infinite amount of randomized worlds to explore and attempt to beat.
*Swaths of items and other hidden content some of which can only be found by exploring new worlds.
*Various difficulty levels which impact the way items, enemies, and events unfold within each world.
*Cute graphical art style, soundtrack, and writing with no filler.

**One Way Heroics Plus should be released soon on steam and it further expands upon the game. It is definitely worth the price of admission.

reviewText: Rogue-like slasher with rpg elements. Nice quick convenient die and build up" your character aspect. Essentially every time you die in trying to beat the game
date: you get better and better equips you can store in your "dimensional" storage which allows you to use it for the next play-through. The catch is that every time you replace previous items you can only use items from that particular play-through. This in turn gets you to use unique classes specifically to collect up amazing gear way later and then die off
recommended: use that gear from the beginning and in turn collect up better gear. Eventually you'll get so epic with unlocked perks and such that the game will be a breeze. It's a fun challenge. 5 hour marker beat it but there is harder modes to play and some replay value involved with different classes and whatnot. :)\n\nUpdate:I have played it a good bit more and there is in total

reviewText: One Way Heroics is a very small game with a surprising amount of depth. I did not really expect much from it when a bought it but for its asking price deserves at least a try. You are a random hero tasked with destroying the evil Demon Lord and to stop the spread of Darkness. The key mechanic is that the Darkness comes from the left and you can only venture right ( One Way Heroics ,duh! ) .  It can create some funny scenarios, trust me. So , if you are able to pick this one up , do it. Its a good, little rogue-like,\nwell worth your time.

reviewText:
Easily one of the best roguelikes out there. I'd put it at number 2 in my book.
The companions are terrific; each have their own stories and quests. I don't think I've ever seen a roguelike with a story that was actually compelling.
The spell casting is phenomenal, something I could never enjoy in Nethack, Slash'em, and other turnbased roguelikes.
Terrific soundtracks, another thing that many roguelikes lack. I'd say on-par, maybe better, than FTL soundtracks.
IMO, this game has an excellent balance of luck vs tactical sense (Its not a total crapshoot but there is enough randomness to make repeat playthroughs rewarding and fun.
Incredible sense of adventure as you flee the oncoming doom from the west; different biomes offer unique challenges and enemies.
Most people don't realize there are actually THREE ways to win. If you think you da man just because you stomped the demon lord, think again. You ain't done yet, lil ♥♥♥♥♥.

And... its 87 cents during sales. You could buy a soda... or you could save half that money and buy a game with at least 20 hours of content. What a time to be alive.

reviewText: This is a fantastic game that's got a lot of replayability, once you get the hang of how basic exploring and decision making needs to be made, it becomes addicting.  This 3 dollar game is going to consume a lot of my time.  I like how each class isn't limited to weapons and armor, and how you can carry over items with the Dimensional Vault.  The items losing durability over time without a solid avenue to keep them repaired just makes you push harder to find new weapons and armor to slay the Demon Lord! A++++ For a unique well put together game.

reviewText:
One Way Heroics surprised me immensely. First time in appeared on Steam it caught my attention because Roguelikes and Roguelites are my passion, but even though the price tag was very tempting I decided to let it go for now.

It wasn't until my friend recommended the game to me that I have decided to try it.

And I was immediately left with good first impression. I always thought sprite graphics looked cute, so regarding this it was great choice by the developers. As it often goes with roguelites, as you progress in the game, either die over and over, or beat the final villain over and over, you unlock more classes, more perks and so, which means that the replay value is quite high.

There are plenty of things to unlock, plenty things to see and I bet you won't see them all even after you invested several hours in the game, I mean, it was just now that I found one recruitable companion who made me appreciate the game even more.

All in all it's and amazing game that is a must buy. For 3 dollars you are getting a real gem.

reviewText:
This game is indeed an RPG, it has difficulty, a lot of things to learn about, everything I expected in an RPG, there are many classes to explore, many different campaigns to check out, the concept of the game is it's sidescroller SORT of turnbased, every action you do will scroll the screen more to the right, the darkness engulfs the left. If you get engulfed it's gameover.

Oh and there's a Demon Lord that chases your ♥♥♥ with a timer clock that indicates when he comes and how long he stays. Also a day and night cycle. NPCs, Dungeons, various monsters. Skill effects, magicks, weapon skills, defense, tactics.

I've played this for 30 minutes and am convinced if you like RPGs you should try this. for 3$, or even 10$ definitely worth it.

The soundtrack is also ear candy.

Only problem is that the resolution is fixed to 640x480, you can stretch it to fullscreen but here's hoping in future updates it'll support larger screen resolutions.

update: hit 22 hours in and am still surprised there's things to discover, also daily campaigns are cool and differ from random generation and you get to gauge with other players online(due to you all being in the same dimension) and meet their ghosts if they met their demise on their way to escape the darkness or to fell the Demon Lord, or perhaps even a greater foe?

reviewText: One Way Heroics is a lot of fun.  It has four difficulties (plus an added setting to make things even harder,) three main endings, as well as several epilogues based on the allies that you manage to recruit along the way, and limitless replay value, thanks to short playtimes, unlockables, and the ability to transfer a limited number of items from one playthrough to the next.  The world is ending, and unlike every other rpg ever made, the threat is very obvious and imminent.  As you run, behind you the world is being devoured by the darkness, and you along with it if you dally.  You have to find the best equipment you can, upgrade it, level up, and recruit any allies that might be willing to help, and stop the Darkness from destroying the world by any means necessary.

reviewText:
By far this game is one of my most favorite  indie games ever. I've played quite a few inclusing Bastion and things like Trine but this is on a different level. Its simple, combat is flawless  and easy to work with. You can survive sometimes by just spamming  'z' on monsters and get away with like 2hp.But the game is not about surving. You need to build up your character, make decisions on whether to give up 5 lvls to increase stats such as strength. There are so many different variations it's nearly endless fun.

There are different gamemodes , many classes with their unique skill set and many types of weapons. Also one of the key things i love about the game is the amount of save files, when they were making this game i'm certai nthey wanted to let ur imagination go wild so they gave u tons X_X
In conclusion, this game will rekindle that feeling you ever had when u played games like Pokemon Mystery Dungeon. Along the way you gain new allies, and based on your choices they might leave as quickly as they go.
BTW THE SOUNDTRACK IS ONE OF THE BEST EVER !

My rate-4.5/5 stars

Have Fun :D

reviewText:
Worth noting:
+It's only like £2, and for that price you get a pretty expansive rouge like.
+Randomly generated areas combined with ticking down clock for boss appearences makes it fun to replay after a while away
+It's got a good gimmick - you have to keep moving right or die, which means movements should be careful.
+Can grab a dimension name from a friend in order to play their experiences, so you can organize group races easily
+Really nice looking GUI, so you don't need a tileset unless you want to mix it up or hate 2d for some reason
-As of right now, there's only like 7 or so classes in the game and about as many perks (excluding stat upgrades), so
-Monster appearence, even on afternoon stroll (normal difficulty) is kinda limited, but I've only just started...
-Offer small dungeons and towns, but the constant eating of the left side of the screen offers little time to reap their benefits

I've not logged as many hours as I'd like into this game, so I may put up a second critique later. But if you've got £2 to spare and want to get started in the rougelike genre, this game is practically a steal. I'd really recommend getting it.

reviewText: An excellent game, able to be played in short bursts or over long periods it offers a good mix of challenge and ease of entry. It has several classes most of which play differently enough to feel like you are actually playing different classes rather than just the same class reskinned twenty times. A surprising variety of enemy types also help to keep the combat fresh and the looming threat of both the demon lord and the darkness keeps things tense as you try to make the best use of what resources and time you have.\n\nTo top it off the random maps mean that while you can have the same adventure over and over if you want to there's always something fresh to do.

reviewText: Fun game, I really recommend it for it's price. Basically, you're just running right in an 8-bit, procedurally-generated world, trying to become as strong as you can by fighting enemies and picking up a ton of different pieces of equipment and items before the final boss of the world comes to ♥♥♥♥ your ♥♥♥♥ up. There's an interesting gimmick involved though, you can't just stop and grind on enemies or bother trying to crack open a chest because darkness is forever swallowing the world from the left. This makes things incredibly interesting, because every step you take is another few pixels or so that the darkness is moving towards you. Every turn" you take to attack
hoursPlayed: every enemy you kill is another chance for the darkness to eat your world. It's really a fun game

reviewText: Don't spend too long hanging around and eating the chef's delicious bread crusts - the world is quickly being covered in darkness and it is your job to head east and slay the Demon Lord. This is a neat game. It respects your time and your wallet. Perfect for those bitesized roguelike cravings but surprisingly rich with content for what it is. During online play you may encounter the helpful ghosts of other players à la Dark Souls who died by the unforgiving hands of roaming monsters. They will give you some experience and ask you to kill the Demon Lord for them. All in all it's fun and it's cheap, so why the heck not.

reviewText:
One Way Heroics has a straightforward but great concept. I was just about to overlook this game and not buy it but brought myself to anyway. Did I regret it? Definitely not. Why? A small price to pay for several hours of game gameplay and replayability. Was it worth it? I don't know about you but if I followed the concept of $1 = 1 hour gameplay" then this is definitely worth lots more than what it's priced at.

-Overviews and stuff- (if you just want the opinion go straight to it)

You play as the "almighty" hero and continue travelling right to take down the demon lord who is slowly consuming the world in darkness. This darkness will continue following you throughout your travels. The game will also happily remind you that the very left side of your screen is death and despair and you don't want to be caught in it otherwise it'll eviscerate you...
...or something along those lines.
There are several dimensions and special ones every now and then. This means you may share a dimension with friends (though you won't see them

reviewText:
One Way Heroics...
Long Version: One Way Heroics is an RPG styled game where you run across the land to fight and prepare for the Dark Lord. You can go online *Warning: Not sure about that part, I haven't tested it.* and play with your friends. Fight vicious dogs and trolls while also buying swords, armor, shields, arrows and more from merchants/dealers
Short Version:
-Start Game
-Get rekt by a cute doggy
-Try again
-Get rekt again
-Cry your heart out
-Raigquit

Rating:
9.5/10
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing.

You start by choosing a class and up to 5 perks, but you will have to unlock most of these first.
It's fun trying different combinations and seeing how they play out.

The map is determined by the seed you choose, you can pick a random one, enter one yourself or choose one of a few daily dimensions that are altered in a special way.
The game is rogue-like and turn-based, dying means perma-death.
During your run you will explore the map, find loot, kill monsters and other enemies, level up, talk to several NPCs who offer various services, recruit NPCs to help you fight and finish your main quest (which is usually killing a boss).

Every turn the darkness behind you consumes a little bit more of the map, so you have to keep progressing forward and think carefully about if you'll have enough time to explore a dungeon or visit a town. Normally this isn't really a problem, you can easily outrun the slowly-progressing darkness.
In case of emergency you can use your Awakening ability up to 5 times, which stops the time for 3 turns so you can get yourself out of trouble.

Usually whenever you die, it is because you weren't careful, you will learn from most deaths.
Most of the time there are ways to save yourself, but you just didn't try or think of everything or were too cocky, though of course there are also times when the game really seems to hate you.

There are multiple endings depending on how you beat the game and which NPC you have with you.
Moreover when you beat the game you can store some items in your vault, which you can choose to use at the beginning of each run.

Lastly, it's a single-player game, but while playing the game online it will show you details about other players who are in the same dimension and occasionally you will meet ghosts of other fallen players who will drop one of their items and give you experience.
Furthermore after clearing a dimension it will show you the characters of everyone who completed it as well.

For the price, especially when it's on sale, it's a steal.
I definitely also recommend buying OWH+ if you already enjoyed the base game, it adds a lot of new content.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Put simply, One Way Heroics is the Heroes of Might and Magic III of turn-based rogue-likes. You should expect to lose several hours at a time with each session. Unlike classic Rogue-Likes (Dungeon Crawl/Elona) I've found that every time I play this, I feel like I discover new ways to play the game. When I lose, rather than becoming discouraged, I find myself eager to try out new builds or adjusting my strategy and seeing how far it will take me.

If you're even considering trying it out, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
If The NeverEnding Story and a turn-based JRPG took a sloppy, unprotected ride on the bone train in the bathroom of a Bon Jovi concert, and then the resulting baby was given up for adoption to be raised by a kind-hearted foster family of addictive indie Rogue-Lites, this is what that child would look like.

If you're a nihilist or a spooky Tim Burton fan, you can repeatedly run into the cold arms of the dark abyss slowly consuming all of reality and celebrate the futility of your existence to your heart's content!! Also there's a dog girl.

15 and a half rapples.

reviewText:
An amazing game, where to start...

You choose your hero, and start in one of the many maps. Embarking on your own epic adventure to escape the never ending darkness that pursues yourself. Mistakes will be made, tough decision lay at every town and dungeon in this race against time. Will you Defeat the demon lord? or will you just keep on running?

For its prices its a steal, a unique take on classic rpg genre. With plenty of replay value, it will keep you coming back to this causle game to unlock every character, characted skin and perks.

10/10

reviewText:
This is a pretty good turn-based RPG for $3. It's short (less than an hour to reach the end) but the replay value is mostly what keeps the game interesting.

You start out with 2 classes and unlock several more as you play through the game's randomly-generated worlds. You can also carry items from game to game, and they'll be available from the start.

As you're forced to keep moving to the right, you have to plan your actions more than you would in something like early Final Fantasy games. You can take things at your own pace for the most part and One Way Heroics isn't too difficult. If you mess up, the game will give you hints, and you have a couple of abilities to make things go easier. If you want a more difficult game you don't have to use them, and there are multiple difficulty settings. Save points can be easy or hard to find, depending on your luck and where you go.

I don't like that weapons and armor have a limited number of uses, but since you can upgrade stuff it would probably be game-breaking to have unlimited uses on things. A couple of playthroughs would give you way-too-powerful weapons.

Overall this is a decent game to get, and the price is adequately low. If you see it on sale for less than $1 you can't go wrong buying One Way Heroics.

It has many features that will suprise you

reviewText:
As I've mentioned before and is somewhat common knowledge about a niche genre, every rogue-like is a balancing act between luck and skill to varying degrees. One Way Heroics, to its credit, trends more toward skill from my play time so far. There are moments of failure, but they are logical moments.

Whoops. Forgot about the scrolling screen of doom."
"Whoops. Ignored the icon above an enemy showing it's a miniboss."
"Whoops. Forgot about my potions."

That's what is refreshing about the game; every failure makes sense. Often
date: that isn't the case in other examples of the genre. Each game has its own unique learning curve and priorities
recommended: of course. But this isn't the kind of game where you decide to drink a potion and roll the dice on it being poison or acid. It's far more structured than that
hoursPlayed: with information clearly presented to the player. This ensures that any difficulty is genuine
voteText: and not just a random number generator. I can appreciate that.\n\nAside from that noteworthy benefit
helpfulPercent: One Way Heroics is pretty cool on its own merits. Classic pixellated graphics aren't rare
votesHelpful: but the game uses them in a charming way rather than seeming budget-minded. The scrolling mechanic is fairly unique
votesTotal: and adds elements of point-focused gaming such as Cannabalt. It's a simple thing
votesFunny: but executed just right to encourage that "one more run" mindset.\n\nIn short: I got this game less than a day ago
commentsCount: and I already feel like I've got my money's worth and then some. Give it a shot.\n\n"

reviewText:
Despite its ridiculously tiny native resolution (which you can scale up) and its random crashes, OWH is a fantastic take on the roguelike, boiled down to its most simplest form - keep moving, and hack at everything.  Well, that's kind of trivializing it a bit as there are a bunch of abilities, weapons, and generally oodles of lootles to find and methods of keeping them from game to game.  There's also a save system, so it's not entirely roguelike at all, but close to a J-ARPG from the dayes of Yore.

Ahem... the main mechanic of the game is that the world is constantly scrolling into oblivion (the game is turn-based so as long as you stand still, nothing happens) and you need to keep moving right until you meet the boss.  If you make it that far.  If you can survive.  If you brought/found the right gear.

Regardless, success or fail, once you've concluded a run, you earn Hero Points in order to unlock character classes, abilities, perks, and most importantly, slots for your DImensional Vault.  Whazzat?  Easy - it's a safe to store items you've found so you can give it to the next hero you roll.  Pretty simple stuff.

Presentation is great, sounds are perfectly retrofit, and the only hit against it (considering this thing is priced less than a hamburger) is that it's a bit unstable.  Good thing there's a save system.

Anyways, if you have money in your pocket, you could spend it on stupider things than One Way Heroics; don't.  This game will satisfy you more than glitter putty ever could.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

As you're forced to keep moving to the right, you have to plan your actions more than you would in something like early Final Fantasy games. You can take things at your own pace for the most part and One Way Heroics isn't too difficult. If you mess up, the game will give you hints, and you have a couple of abilities to make things go easier. If you want a more difficult game you don't have to use them, and there are multiple difficulty settings. Save points can be easy or hard to find, depending on your luck and where you go.

I don't like that weapons and armor have a limited number of uses, but since you can upgrade stuff it would probably be game-breaking to have unlimited uses on things. A couple of playthroughs would give you way-too-powerful weapons.

Overall this is a decent game to get, and the price is adequately low. If you see it on sale for less than $1 you can't go wrong buying One Way Heroics.

reviewText:
So no bulls-hit, One Way Heroics is possibly my favorite game of the year so far. It's neck and neck with Banner Saga, and though Banner Saga definitely has a greater immersion factor, the pick-up-and-play roguelike aspects and the replayability of OWH put it over the top.

What you have here is a game with the energy and fun of a classic Japanese RPG on the Super Nintendo, but with the ruthless difficulty and randomness of a roguelike. However, the developer very wisely simplifies the roguelike formula, so that you are not playing an overly complicated survival simulation; you are playing a game that feels both fun and intense; it is demanding of your judgment without being a drain on the limits of your attention span.

It's not perfect; once you've seen the 3 or 4 variations of towns" and "dungeons" in the game they'll get stale quick. Enemy and landscape variety becomes a little threadbare after a few (successful) playthroughs as well. Also
recommended: the characters are ridiculously small. Don't even bother trying to play in windowed mode. You might as well go outside and stare at ants.\n\nThe achievements are very good as well; they're almost all challenge-oriented
hoursPlayed: encouraging you to push your skills to their limit
voteText: rather than go out of your way to fulfill random garbage achievements (I'm looking at you
helpfulPercent: Rogue's Tale).\n\nOne Way Heroics is a badass game
votesHelpful: especially for the price."

reviewText:
For being so cheap, this game was an amazing fun surprise. It's a fairly simple roguelike that's really quick (1-2 hours) and rewarding, has a lot of different classes to play, four difficulties, multiple endings, and has different maps and challenges every day.

Every adventure earns you hero points, which you can use to buy new perks or shared bank space (to hand down items to new characters) after you die or win.

There are multiplayer feeds that show what other players are doing at the same time, and you'll often encounter helpful ghosts of players who died in that dimension. At the end of each adventure you can get a scrolling credit-roll of all the heroes who won.

Great simple and fun game, and highly replayable.

reviewText:
As I've mentioned before and is somewhat common knowledge about a niche genre, every rogue-like is a balancing act between luck and skill to varying degrees. One Way Heroics, to its credit, trends more toward skill from my play time so far. There are moments of failure, but they are logical moments.

Whoops. Forgot about the scrolling screen of doom."
"Whoops. Ignored the icon above an enemy showing it's a miniboss."
"Whoops. Forgot about my potions."

That's what is refreshing about the game; every failure makes sense. Often
date: that isn't the case in other examples of the genre. Each game has its own unique learning curve and priorities
recommended: of course. But this isn't the kind of game where you decide to drink a potion and roll the dice on it being poison or acid. It's far more structured than that
hoursPlayed: with information clearly presented to the player. This ensures that any difficulty is genuine
voteText: and not just a random number generator. I can appreciate that.\n\nAside from that noteworthy benefit
helpfulPercent: One Way Heroics is pretty cool on its own merits. Classic pixellated graphics aren't rare
votesHelpful: but the game uses them in a charming way rather than seeming budget-minded. The scrolling mechanic is fairly unique
votesTotal: and adds elements of point-focused gaming such as Cannabalt. It's a simple thing
votesFunny: but executed just right to encourage that "one more run" mindset.\n\nIn short: I got this game less than a day ago
commentsCount: and I already feel like I've got my money's worth and then some. Give it a shot.\n\n"

reviewText: I'll admit my first half hour with this game was a bit frustrating but once you get used to the gameplay it becomes extremely addicting. reviewText:
Great game for a low price!

We've all spent a good deal of money on the latest game only to be disappointed by the results. One Way Heroics take the approach where they sell their product cheap so that gamers will not feel cheated in the unlikely event that they do not like it.

The formula is ridiculously simple. Think of one of the old school Final Fantasy games where you walk from town to town facing random enemies. This basically sums up a good deal of this game. Sure there is a demon lord and classes, but it is very simplistic in nature.

My old gripe with the game is that you basically start off from scratch every time you play it. To me this says that your last question meant nothing, start over.

The good thing about it is that there are literally infinite possibilities as the universe randomly generates names, creatures, treasures, etc. Easy to lose yourself in it.

reviewText:
Warning: Not to be underestimated.

One-Way Heroics combines turn-based combat, side scrolling arcade style gameplay, limited saves, and a hearty dose of classic RPG nostalgia. It also ranks in difficulty with the likes of Mega-Man, Ninja Gaiden, and Castlevania.
The foundation of Heroics would make it seem like two things that should never go together.
On the left side of the screen, the world fades into a Darkness that consumes men, women,  children, small animals, dungeon bosses, buildings, eveything. It is your job to find out what is causing the darkness by travelling to the ends of the earth and defeating the source (oh, and the final boss has finally attained some common sense, and will randomly spawn in an effort to kill you before you get enough power and equipment to wreck his world.)  It would start to sound as if it's an infinite runner (akin to Temple Run and Flappy Bird).
And then there are the RPG elements.
Randomly generated worlds, item upgrades, exploration, looting, unlockable perks and classes, the element of permadeath between save points (random enemy drops and treasures will not be the same after continuing from a save file), and the random enemy attributes lead one to question their sanity.
Each playthrough is different. You have the option to create a new random world every time that you start a new game, but you can also play through the same world as different classes.
There are 8 different classes in total, (Only the Knight and Swordmaster are available at the start, but with additional playthroughs, the roster expands with Hunter, Pirate, Bard, Adventurer, Force User, and Hero) with very different play styles. Swordmasters are tough, but it comes at a cost to stamina and carrying capacity. Hunters, however, are better suited to stealth, ranged weapons, and have a special ability that allows them to see off-screen enemies before they encounter them.
All in all, it's got great addictive gameplay, the sprite animations are charming, the music is fantastic , and I would give this an 8-8.5

reviewText:
Saw a friend of mine got this game, and I noticed it was on sale for $1...  So, I thought I'd grab myself a copy; I was very much satisfied. :owforce:

One Way Heroics, being a rogue-like on the run, is quite a fun experience.  I was afraid it would be extremely time limit based, which I despise, but I was thankfully proven wrong.  While you do always have to be on the run from the shadowy darkness from the left, you can play a pretty much infinite game...  Just, be aware things will get stronger, and that the Demon Lord will continuously hunt your butt down.

While I extremely enjoy this game, the friend I saw buy this, did not.  This game is not for everyone, but to give you an idea of the games I like, you could say this game is similar, but on a certain degree, to...  FTL: Faster Than Light and Dungeons of Dredmor.

If you're still not quite sure, and if $3.49 is still a bit much for you, I highly suggest picking up a copy when it goes on sale, even one as low as 25% off. :3

reviewText: Need a quick-break game where you must progress or die? Where no two games are the same? This game is for you. Generate a hero and go east (right), as you don't want the darkness to catch you. Run into herbs, towns, monsters, weapons, upgrade, trade, and more. You can even transfer a thing or two to your reincarnation (i.e. next game) to help yourself along. And listen to your spirit guide who will give you critique on how you did (good or bad) and how to do better.\n\nGraphics are low and 8-bit, and it's really turned based, but it's quick fun. Find it cheap, have a little fun. It's not cheap.

reviewText:
This is the sort of game that feels really well realized.

The gimmick of One Way Heroics is the constant movement of the screen to the right. This may seem like a simple mechanic, or maybe something that would limit the fun you could have, but it's honestly what makes this game so addicting.

You have to plan ahead. If you blindly rush into any dungeon you see you'll likely find yourself stuck behind a wall, frantically trying to break it down as the darkness creeps up from behind. You have to consider whether you can clear it before the darkness catches up, whether you have the HP and gear required to take on the monsters inside, and whether to advance into a room or wait and let the mobs come at you one by one.

It encourages you to pack all those items that you'd discard without a second thought in other games. Scroll of Confusion? Use it on the Demon Lord so you can run away while he flails randomly. Teleportation Pill? Use it when caught behind a mountain range and pray it drops you on the other side. (Seriously, watch the map. Mountains are just as dangerous as monsters.) Nayuta Fruit? Use it when in a snow area to replenish your energy. Big stone? . . . Leave it, this one is actually useless.

The character classes are reasonably varied. Each class starts with different stats and abilities depending on what their purpose is. For instance, the Knight has the Great Wall ability, which lets him regen health every turn. While the Bard has the Song of Heroism, which increases party members damage and defence. There's also an adventurer class, with stats that make him perfect for stashing as much loot as possible.

The world generation is simple, but effective. You'll be seeing the same tiles over and over again, with few real differences between the biomes. Thing is, it's the layout that matters, not the scenery. It's the generation of Alters of the Goddess, towns, Dark Brotherhood hidouts, and Golems (Be very prepared before you try to take these things on) that make each new world interesting.

After each run you'll be awarded Hero Points which you can spend to unlock new perks, classes, and expand your Vault. (In which you can store items from your previous run, in order to use them in the next.)

The last feature, and judging from the other reviews here also the most unappreciated, are the story missions. These change every day, one day you'll be accompanied by the healer Dosey, the next you'll be tasked with rescuing the Queen. Each of these NPCs have different stories which you'll learn more about as you fight with them. These really make adventuring more interesting, and are a nice addition to the game. They didn't have to be there, but it's nice that they are.

One Way Heroics is, in my opinion, criminally underpriced. I fully recommend picking this up.

reviewText:
Welcome to the world of One Way Heroics.
You can play as multiple characters while you travel to the right side of the map at all times for a great darkness follows and swallows the world behind you. Do you have what it takes to manage the up coming challenges and escape the creeping death while facing the dangers ahead?

Starting off the king sends you upon a journey to escape the darkness and find the truth of what is happening to the world, you take the challenge before you and must move and leave behind the castle. Once on the move you must use cunning and skill in a semi turned based, rogue-like, RPG full of challenges. Bosses await your arrival at certain intervals, the randomly generated map will keep you on your toes. Decisions will have you staring at your screen for minutes at a time. Should you use that ability to save your life or keep pushing yourself to the limit for the slim chance of victory.

I expect to be placing alot more time into this gem. It has an excellent amount of difficulty and a very unique type of gameplay with the grid system, in-depth attributes, weapon enchanting, and item management.

I highly recommend this game, thanks for reading.
