reviewText:
Taking One Way Heroics to a new level, Plus adds almost double the content with new classes, enemies, features and more. Defeat the Demon Lord in a whole different dimension with this unmissable addition.

Literlly the DLC and the Whole entire game in a nutshell

If you are a fan of Rouge like Dungeons / Openworlds like Minecraft - Binding Of Issac series, and Cyrpt of the Necrodancer. Then this game is also a must in your inventory of wonderous games.

I personally would like to say I spent countless hours offline and online on this game. Trust me, it may look low now. But I spent 100+ of hours playing this... Why? I had worlds to explore. I maybe explored over 1000+ worlds and yet have to save not even 40% of them yet.

You get to choose your class and you are already set to go on a journey of a everlasting battle of darkness. Not only that,  the darkness is actually a dragon!  is also a very impending doom of your very world you travel and  saving!

Fear not, you have time on your hand. No joke, time is of the essance and so is key placement, fighting, item usage and your weapon durability. May I also say you have a day/night cycle? Vision ? More over that you have Bonuses and debuffs? Even more so you can find allies! Even if you're willing to sacrifice some of your levels,  A bard and hero is more sufficient in creating a co-op NPC!  you can obtain some Cooperating Enemies or other misc!.

The content of the first game is already a great stand alone game. But the expansion far over gives it more power and bang for your buck. Even at a sale price, the game is fantastic. The updates are nearly weekly and they are on the clock * LOL PUNS* constantly checking for bugs and patching new campaigns.

The classes are easy to understand, the game mechanics simply easy to use, and if delt well , very useful to master. As time, placements, and generally the whole landscape. You too can already learn the many ways of becoming heroic.

There is also a _Afterdeath_ Screen where you can save, trade, expend, repair, and increase your items you collected in your traveling of the worlds. Hell you can even gain items you can't get in certain campaings. But if you complete it , you gain special other perks, even endings you can get if you finally get them!

Game has perks in it... PERKS! Even Debuffs that make your heroic level skyrocket, but not for the faint of heart. As the Debuffs increase levels, yes, but make your game FAR more Harder and more time pinching then the other easy pickings. Even if you think you got a nice going class you like and you unlock another and gain them the right set for them. You want to try to get more classes.

The DLC does that for you, it adds 4 more classes, ON TOP with more perks, settings, increase in more items, drops, enemies. Even more campaigns you can do in your  Castle Renavations and also other main / side quests!  More toys to find. Even going beyond the limit. The world never ends.

The Pros
Rouge Like - Infinite Possiblities
Low Price
Trading Cards
Retro Gameplay with innovative tactics.
Weekly Updates / New Campaigns
Great for Game Stuffers and Collectors!
Great storyline - Mini Campaigns with Plots and Events
Great Quick Game for short players - Walk in the Park if you have a break in your schedule!
The Cons

Time Waster - Somewhat good too.
Slightly challenging to a new RPG Player if not prepared -  Be Fairly Warned - If going for harder campaigns and doing it for cheevies, I suggest trying to use Hero / Knight Classes to survive if not, Bet your heroic tush goodbye! [spoiler/]
No Multiplayer Base - But What you expect? I said *Co-op* but it's your Allies you make in game.
Options and HUD UI a bit ... Cluttered but I let it slide as it trying to keep all your info in the game as you travel without the need of constant back tracking.
All in All A very great game, I love it, I play it, I am Addictted to it.

In my score I give it 9.2 / 10 Review

9.5/10 - Gameplay
9.0/10 - Music / OST
9.0/10 - Graphics
8.5/10 - Storyline
10/10  - Creativity and Originality

reviewText: Iris is qt3.14\n\nSeriously though, this is a cute little time-killer sidescrolling roguelite with a mechanic that forces you to move forward or be swallowed by the encroaching darkness coming from the left side of the screen. Simple mechanic, but effective (should I risk racing for that chest I just spotted near the left or move on?) Very lighthearded, doesn't take itself seriously at all. Pretty satisfying, with solid turn-based grid gameplay and plenty of fun classes and skills to unlock.

reviewText:
Looks pretty simple, but that's just on the surface.
Don't let the permadeath hold you back. Unlike other games, this is just a drawback, but not a hassle that makes you want to stop playing for weeks untill you calm down. It makes me think of Hotline Miami, where death just pushes you further.
Another plus is that you can store powerful items when you finish playing, so you can have them from the start on new games (although I wouldn't recommend that, since it somehow ruins the experience).
Add an aleatory map generation system, an animal-lover guild, bandits, and the overkill of the left side of the screen (for real).

Cheapest game deserving a 9/10 I've ever played.

reviewText:
So close to being a perfect game.

The only painfully glaring development flaws are that potential party members (and other frendly NPCs) often get killed by monsters before even appearing on the screen (the game loads a ways ahead of what is accessible), and that several of your own abilities will kill or harm cooperative NPCs that are following you, i.e. mercenaries, cows, packhorses, etc.

All that aside it's an amazingly addictive and satisfying game, one which hopefully inspires future developers to do it right.

reviewText:
*tl;dr:
This game is basically walking to the right side, while avoiding the darkness that keeps eating everything from the left side, with RPG elements and randomized world.*


-The game has different classes.
-Each world is different (randomized).
-The game has good difficulty modes (They are not too easy and not inhumanly hard)
-You level up your character, by gaining exp from creatures that spawn around the world or in dungeons.
-The game has multiple classes that you need to unlock. Each class has different strenghts and weaknesses.
-Each class levels different stats up faster. For example the sorcerer levels inteligents faster than the knight class.
-Story is scattered. You need to beat the game multiple times on different difficulties and with different characters, to find out more about the story.
-Great replay value if you like walking east every time.

Overall I'd say this is a good game for the completionists, who dont mind doing the same thing in a randomized world over and over again.

I wouldn't recommend buying this if you're not planning on spending hours unlocking the characters and the different endings or difficulties.

DLC EDIT:

-Monster spawn more and items spawn randomly, so no more waiting or sitting around
-More items have been added and the spawn rate has been reworked so powerfull items are more rare
-More story has been added and the main story has been completed.
-Mini bosses have been added
-Random events have been added
-More terrain has been added
-More NPC's and shops/dungeons have been added

The DLC is a great addition to the game, the events, mini bosses and random loot will keep you busy during your runs, while the extra quests and companions will keep you coming back for more.

(I apologise for my bad english)

reviewText:
Oh my oh my, why I have I passed this up so many times before in the weekly bargain bin - there is a darn good reason this has overwhelmingly positive reviews. This is such a wonderful mix of rogueLIKE (turn-based combat), and Final Fantasy, without the menu-based combat. Metric tons of meta-game unlockables, which I totally love. So much game here, its a shame how underpriced it is.

Don't let the JRPG/RPG-Maker graphics turn you off, this is not some weekend project - it is very well crafted and totally original.

Pros:
+Totally addicting roguelike game
+Tons of gameplay to be had - and I haven't even touched the multiplayer/online map portion, which looks super fun
+I love the meta-game unlockables; they remind me alot of Rogue Legacy
+There is also an item vault similar to in ToME
+Price is stupid low
+Definately alot to learn a la BoI style - knowledge is definately rewarded here
+I really appreciate games that only use the keyboard - allows for easy laptop play, but I must add that controller support is great here too
+Music is totally good classic RPG style ballads

Cons:
-The graphics and JRPG structure will certainly turn alot of people off at first glance - it did for me - but it shouldn't!
-Some wonky resolution options on the bigscreen, but I did find a fix that I still need to try
-With complexity, there always comes a medium- to fairly steep learning curve

Totally worth the money, hands down.

reviewText:
The best roguelike on Steam

Bold statement, but it truly is. The game forces you to constantly advance and that really gives the game a very good pacing; the interface isn't clunky which often is the case with more traditional roguelikes, but the game doesn't dumb down anything either.

The game got an amazing attention to details, and lots of effort has clearly been put into things that most will never notice, but that really makes the game worth replaying over and over against, because you always find new things every time. Clearing the game first looks very simplistic, but once you defeat the demon lord you'll realize that there's far more to the game than you thought.

The graphics aren't impressive, but they work well for the game, and the artwork can be quite charming at times.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You are a hero.  There's a darkness steadily advancing from the left.  If you get caught in it, it kills you, so you'll be steadily advancing to the right.  There's a demon lord that'll show up at some point to try to kill you.  It's your job to kill him first.  That's pretty much the story.
This is essentially a turn based RPG.  Every step you take, action you make, etc. is matched by both the encroaching darkness and all other creatures/NPCs in the game.  As you progress right, you'll run into friendly NPCs that can sell/buy/give items, enemies that want to end your quest, random items strewn across the landscape...pretty much everything you'd expect from an RPG.
The worlds you'll play on are randomly generated, so you have the option of a new map each time you play, although you also have the option of playing a world you or someone else has already played by inputting a code.  So, if you find a world you like, you can keep returning to it, or you can keep exploring new layouts...although if you return to a dimension already visited, there will still be some things that change, as shops will have different stocks and random item drops will be different.
You start out with two classes available(and a male and female skin for each one), and as you either perform tasks during your attempts(killing an enemy with a bow, for example, unlocks the Hunter class) or spend the points you accumulate at the end of each run, you will unlock more classes and various boosts for your characters, known as perks.
There's something about this game that keeps managing to pull me back in, even after it humiliates me.  This game is not much in the way of being forgiving.  Your character is pretty weak to start out each run, and there's always a good chance that a fairly strong monster will be hanging around a few meters from the start to make you notice just how weak you are, and there are always chances you'll take the wrong path through some terrain and get pinned behind a wall of mountains that you won't be able to cross before the darkness catches you.  But, even with that, there's always a chance the next run will drop off an awesome weapon early on, or the planets will align perfectly and you'll take a golden path through the land and take down the Demon Lord with ease...only to never be able to recreate that run again.

So yes.  I highly recommend this game.

reviewText: First off, you start off as a hero and you're trying to defeat the demon lord in order to stop the darkness that is following you and eating up the world. It's a very generic premise, but the thing is: There is no turning back. If you miss a shop keeper, you have to restart the world, or keep on going. You're hungry? You just missed the last piece of food for a while? Well too bad. This game has tons of replayability in it, and really is just one way. The levels are randomly generated and there are daily quests every day. Of course you don't get anything out of the daily quests, but they're still fun to adventure through when you really have nothing much to do.\n\nEach run can last more than 45 minutes if you're lucky, but they can also last less than 5 minutes. This game has tons of decision making and luck based things, but it feels perfectly balanced to me. There's a pixie in your inventory to help you with tips so that might help as well. Anyways, the game is well worth the purchase.

reviewText: On my first round I tried to talk to the people in the house you spawn in and my screen kept moving. At first I thought it was a bug I was like uh okay I'll just restart my game later, but nope it kept moving. As I saw my character die while walking towards it I was regretting my purchase. I watched the replay of my death and it was the lamest thing I've ever seen.\nI restarted and the screen was moving again. Suddenly, I realized that this is ONE way heroics which means you either stick to the right or you die. The game just got a whole lot more interesting and I've been enjoying it a lot. A lot of surprises and you can unlock more perks/characters. Best 87 cents you can spend.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. It has a combat system similar to what you would find on one of the Pokemon Dungeon games, which is one of my favorites.
You don't have a whole lot of classes to choose from, but you wouldn't expect to at the price. You still have enough to keep you busy for hours on end.
Each run scores you based off your treasure looted compared to treasure possible to loot, monsters killed without being hit, distance traveled, and your overall level. There are some other minor point contributors, but with those four main ones, it means getting to a high score means you have to be focused and make good use of everything you see.

I would recomend this game to anyone who has free time, because it will eat up a whole lot of yours.

reviewText:
A brilliant and unexpected mixed-itteration of roguelike/rpg.  Go in blind.  The game throws a lot of subtle class and humor, along with solid game play, try everything, don't be too afraid, you can't really mess this one up, because the game didn't.

Does almost everything right except maybe the resolution, which can be a problem for steam announcements, as they get in the way of play.

For the price, maybe one of the best cost/playtime ratios of any game out there.  Highly recomend to anyone who is a fan of either roguelike or RPG.

reviewText: Very enjoyable! The game is quite simple, and fast paced. It's fun how to see your character grow while you travel to defeat the final boss. reviewText: One Way Heroics is a unique game. While at first it seems a little grindy and nearly as death embracing as Dark Souls underneath this veneer the game sparkles. It has some great classic (cliche if you will) story segments that are randomly generated each time you restart and also it has a slight dry humor to some dialogue whichis quite refreshing. The music is beautiful and suits the game and does not become annoying. Perhaps the most astounding thing is that the creator found that other game creators couldn't meet his system needs so he built his own! (WolfRPG) which is quite a feat. Though it would be hard to integrate some multiplayer DLC or sequel would be a great addition to this title. I highly recommend this since it comes at such a low price!

reviewText:
Quite honestly one of the best roguelike RPG's i've played.

There's a character creation system with a variety of classes, perks and appearances. Most need to be unlocked but there's quite a lot to get.

The movement and battles are turn-based and the unique flavor to this particular game is a encroaching wall of darkness from the left that closes in each time you do something.(Move, attack, etc) This means you have to keep a eye on the darkness and consider wether to go on or maybe try to clear that one dungeon or pick up that one item in time.

This creates a sense of pressure that makes for a fun atmosphere.
There is a online aspect to the game in the form of death/milestone messages from other players in the same world that show up in the upper left of the screen.

The worlds are randomly generated but there are specific types that have special quests or certain restrictions. There is also the ability to share world ID's with others so they can play the same world.

For a fairly cheap price this is a great game to pick up.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has brought me back to a genre of cutthroat, 'save/load', challenges that I truly miss in most of my modern day RPG's. Difficulty has become such a turn-style feature that when you choose to baby yourself, you limit your enjoyment and the unique experience each games environment can provide. This game provides one of the best examples of 'bang-for-your-buck' by all the challenges you can face and all of the strategies you can employ through a side-scrolling adventure/RPG.
Be prepared to die, sometimes ridiculously.
Be creative with exploration, the game rewards you by traversing the generated world; but with that said the more curious you become, the more difficult the challenges you may face.
Enjoy!

reviewText: A+ game, well worth the small price. It's got endless replay value thanks to the randomly-generated terrain, and it can be extremely challenging, especially on Afternoon Stroll and higher. There's also an enormous amount of lore contained within the game if you play enough (surprising, considering it's a new game every time you start). All the various classes have different ways to play, and both the skills you learn and the items you find can make or break your playthrough (especially against the Demon Lord; many times have I gone up against him and lost because my weapons were crap). TL;DR 10/10, would buy again

reviewText:
So for those who don't know what this game is, let me first explain what my impression (and the tldr) of the game is:

One Way Heroics is a new twist on (somewhat) rogue-like RPG's, bearing similarities to Shiren the Wanderer (the non-Atlus-screwed-up one) but with an urgency placed on time and what you do with it.

Understandably, some people wouldn't call it a roguelike because of the save/load feature or the dimensional vault, but since you do not accumulate hero points after resuming a loaded game (after death), my interpretation has been that saving/loading is only a feature for those who are in it for the story content.  A good compromise imo.

What I liked

A creative take on this style of game.  I haven't seen anything like it -- the closest comparison would be Shiren the Wanderer.

An objective (the demon lord) that plagues you from the start, but not impossible to vanquish once you have progressed enough.

Party members that serve a purpose, but also have depth.  Like everything else in the game, they are not permanent.

The music is fantastic.


What I didn't like that others might like

I'm not a fan of visual novels (?), so the abundance of text serving as the beginning and end of your adventure is not something that is fulfilling for me.  It's very well written, imo, so I imagine JRPG / Story-reading fans will like this.

No cursed items.  Unidentified items you can wear, but none of them cursed. :\  The only undiscovered attribute on an item that poses any uncertainty is the durability.

The price is so low, it feels like I robbed some poor hard-working developer that just loves making games like this.  Playism's site says something about letting you pay what you want (donation-based I guess?), so hopefully some people have been more charitable towards this game.


What I don't like

There is no way to isolate the leaderboards to personal social groups - as a result, it's all meaningless information, sadly. :\  It would be great if I could see where I rate among my friends list.

There's no underground -- Yah, it's a pretty big game already, sure.  But fantasy games need dungeons.  An intricate right-way-progressing dungeon would've made the screen edge much more intimidating.


Those are my impressions of this game. :)
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this on a whim due to the low price. Have to say it's worth far more. I've already spent more time on this game then Dungeons of Dredmor, and can imagine playing it even more.

Unlike most roguelikes, it's fast paced and easy to get into, but becomes complex once you know the basics. I beat easy difficulty on only my second playthrough, which took around 30 minutes. Normal difficulty adds recruitable party members, new items, and removes the fixed end point in easy mode. My longest run lasted 3 hours. I have yet to beat hard

There are very un-roguelike save points and 'Dimensional Vault' to carry over items from old characters. Your end game rewards are reduced for using them though. If you are good enough at roguelikes to do without them, it's worth trying as there is a lot of stuff to unlock.

reviewText: This game is very innovative, and whilst playing I can't help but bring to mind Half Minute Hero as well. If you've played that and enjoyed it, you'll love this. This game is very fast paced, and if somehow you manage to plow your way through it immediately (good luck) you will have only spent 30 minutes on it. However, the game's replay-ability is it's biggest feature. Each victory ends with more loot, more rewards, more knowledge, and more challenging modes to continue playing with. The game is endless hours of fun, and I must say it is well worth the small amount of money it costs. ($3.00 For anything that lasts for hours and hours is a good deal, regardless of what your interests are.)

reviewText:
It's basically a JRPG combined with a roguelike. There's a big amount of content for the price (which is even cheaper if you buy it off of Playism), including varied classes, daily challenges/runs, hidden endings, and more. It's not too difficult for beginners to get into, but hardcore roguelike fans will still find challenge in the harder difficulty modes. It's really addicting to see how far you can get in a few hours, and you can compare how well you're doing against other players on the same seed in real-time (you can even post your wins/losses on Twitter #OneWayHeroics).

Some people might complain about its lack of depth; don't expect a complex turn-based combat system like in Final Fantasy or a deeply complicated and engaging story. The real fun in this game is in how easy it is to pick up and play. It's definitely worth the price, and it has way more replay value than most of the games priced at $5 - $10 here.

TL;DR - Probably the most fun, easily accessible Roguelike you'll find on Steam that's under $5. :)

reviewText: One Way Heroics is a unique game. While at first it seems a little grindy and nearly as death embracing as Dark Souls underneath this veneer the game sparkles. It has some great classic (cliche if you will) story segments that are randomly generated each time you restart and also it has a slight dry humor to some dialogue whichis quite refreshing. The music is beautiful and suits the game and does not become annoying. Perhaps the most astounding thing is that the creator found that other game creators couldn't meet his system needs so he built his own! (WolfRPG) which is quite a feat. Though it would be hard to integrate some multiplayer DLC or sequel would be a great addition to this title. I highly recommend this since it comes at such a low price!

reviewText:

reviewText:
Quite honestly one of the best roguelike RPG's i've played.

There's a character creation system with a variety of classes, perks and appearances. Most need to be unlocked but there's quite a lot to get.

The movement and battles are turn-based and the unique flavor to this particular game is a encroaching wall of darkness from the left that closes in each time you do something.(Move, attack, etc) This means you have to keep a eye on the darkness and consider wether to go on or maybe try to clear that one dungeon or pick up that one item in time.

This creates a sense of pressure that makes for a fun atmosphere.
There is a online aspect to the game in the form of death/milestone messages from other players in the same world that show up in the upper left of the screen.

The worlds are randomly generated but there are specific types that have special quests or certain restrictions. There is also the ability to share world ID's with others so they can play the same world.

For a fairly cheap price this is a great game to pick up.

reviewText: Very fun indie rogue-lite JRPG. I think it's one of the more overlooked games on Steam which is a shame because it really is good, especially for its price. Basically the game is about you playing the role of the hero, and you have to venture through the land to kill the Demon Lord. You pick your name, class, perks, and start your adventure in a castle full of helpful knights that can give you advice, and also a fairy partner that you bring with you on your adventure to give you advice throughout the game. It won't be easy due to all the wild animals, bandits, monsters, and even the environments, and it's all randomly generated to boot. To top it all off, you absolutely cannot let the black darkness on the left of the screen reach you. Throughout the game the darkness will slowly creep up to you and try to engulf you. Although you move much faster than the darkness itself, doing things like moving through mountains and water, or exploring towns and dungeons for too long will eventually cause the darkness to reach you. The game has a lot of tactics involved as in you have to try and make the most out of the various dungeons you come across, or else you will either get almost nothing out of them or end up dying due to the darkness. Time doesn't move when you're standing still doing nothing, so you can plan out everything. You also have to be very wary of the enemies the game throws at you. If you're not careful and don't take control of the battle, you'll end up finding yourself in a lot of trouble as they are quite strong. Look for various Weapons and Armors you can find because they will most likely be upgrades to your starting equipment. Eventually at 400km the Demon Lord will confront you for a final battle, he has barriers and a lot of HP. Throw everything you can at him, and eventually reinforcements will come to help you. Once you defeat him, you will see the credits, and beat the game...well sort of. See after the end of every run, whether it be due to death or completion, the game will score you on how well you did and you will receive Hero Points. You can use these Hero Points to expand your dimensional vault (A vault where you can store your treasures to use in other runs), unlock new perks and classes etc. This gives the game a ton of replay value as you have to complete the game multiple times to unlock everything. There are some problems I do have with the game, unfortunately. For starters it's quite clunky where you have to manually aim your attacks at enemies and you have to look in the menu to select an ability/item, and your movement speed is quite slow. Fortunately I hear the Plus version which I haven't played yet fixes all of those issues and and adds more content as well. I give the game an 8/10.

reviewText:
tl;dr- Seriously. You like JRPGs? Buy this game. You like persistant unlockables? Buy this game. You like random levels? Buy this game. This is one of my favorite games out there. Its fun to sit and play for 15 mins - or 4 hours straight.

Also - be happy knowing you're supporting 16-bit style WITHOUT USING RPGMaker. This game runs its own engine.

___________________________________________

At first glance, One Way Heroics looks like it was made on RPGMaker. It wasn't. Its a completely custom engine, from someone in Japan.

The description on the store page really doesn't do it justice. It explains the base game. But it doesn't explain how incredibly addicting it is to go just one more run".

reviewText:
This game has brought me back to a genre of cutthroat, 'save/load', challenges that I truly miss in most of my modern day RPG's. Difficulty has become such a turn-style feature that when you choose to baby yourself, you limit your enjoyment and the unique experience each games environment can provide. This game provides one of the best examples of 'bang-for-your-buck' by all the challenges you can face and all of the strategies you can employ through a side-scrolling adventure/RPG.
Be prepared to die, sometimes ridiculously.
Be creative with exploration, the game rewards you by traversing the generated world; but with that said the more curious you become, the more difficult the challenges you may face.
Enjoy!

reviewText:
Interesting? Yes. Entertaining? Yes. Cutesy? Yes. Frustrating? Perhaps. Addictive? Most definitely.

One Way Heroics is a nice little game created in Wolf RPG Editor. When I first played it, I was excited. Games like this always caught my eye and the dialogue the characters/NPC's have only made it more fun. A tad bit silly, but nonetheless still great. So, I started it up and was ready to play. I thought it would be rather simple. It looked easy enough to do; Avoid the darkness consuming the world. In other words, avoid getting scrolled off the screen. I fought monsters along the way. It was very tedious, sure, but entertaining. Then, finally, I encountered the boss, the Demon Lord. I swear, I have never been defeated so quickly by a boss in my entire lifetime.

Eager to defeat him, I retried. And thus started the endless cycle of trying to successfully defeat the Demon Lord.

This game is a bundle of joy, frustration, and addiction. You are provided with numerous classes to choose from and to defeat the Demon Lord with. Each world is randomly generated so there are always new surprises to look forward to. You are also given opportunities to save here and there, so if you are absolutely certain this particular world is suitable for you to achieve your goals, then save at a save point and viola! No need to worry about losing your progress. There are also a number of skills you can obtain, as well as weapons, armor, items, partners - you name it. In addition to the gameplay, the soundtrack is beautiful, enjoyable, and is certainly enough to keep you motivated. Obviously, the graphics are pixelated (with the exception of when character dialogue pops up), but the art is nice and I will admit that I find some of the monsters rather cutesy.

I somehow managed to hop off this game for a while (which was good because if I hadn't, it would've been an unhealthy addiction for me), but I have taken note that the One Way Heroics Plus DLC is coming around Steam sometime soon, so I'll definitely be playing soon again. Do I recommend this game? Of course I do! If you choose to purchase this game, I now wish you all the good luck on your journey to defeat the Demon Lord!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's really fun. You'll stumble around for hours until you start to figure out the little secrets to winning. By no means easy, but despite the simple nature of the game it completely hooks you and you lose about 20 hours in a week to it.\n\nIf you want to know what it plays like, imagine how Binding of Issac uses seeds to determine items and layout (only you're not punished for using them), then imagine you play bumper cars (ie ram them) with enemies to damage them and finally  add some multiplayer" where you can see progress of other adventures in the same seed. If they die

reviewText:
Forced-Sidescroller meets RPG in a game where the world can be generated a hundred different ways.

Good notes: High customization options, good feedback system to help you out, unlockable content makes each run feel like a step forward, replay data is semi-entertaing to watch, and a system with depth to items/combat.

Neutral notes: Well executed 8 bit stlying, faux-multiplayer in which you interact with the dead and recieve semi-selective notes from other players (only available in that day's multiverse world).

Bad notes:  Even on full screen the text may still seem a bit small and some world combinations (I've only found 2 and have entered no less than 25 worlds) are less than enjoyable due to constant mountains or being nearly devoid of interactable content(villages/dungeons/chests)

With all of that said, I give this a full recomendation if you enjoy a rogue-like.

reviewText: Very fun indie rogue-lite JRPG. I think it's one of the more overlooked games on Steam which is a shame because it really is good, especially for its price. Basically the game is about you playing the role of the hero, and you have to venture through the land to kill the Demon Lord. You pick your name, class, perks, and start your adventure in a castle full of helpful knights that can give you advice, and also a fairy partner that you bring with you on your adventure to give you advice throughout the game. It won't be easy due to all the wild animals, bandits, monsters, and even the environments, and it's all randomly generated to boot. To top it all off, you absolutely cannot let the black darkness on the left of the screen reach you. Throughout the game the darkness will slowly creep up to you and try to engulf you. Although you move much faster than the darkness itself, doing things like moving through mountains and water, or exploring towns and dungeons for too long will eventually cause the darkness to reach you. The game has a lot of tactics involved as in you have to try and make the most out of the various dungeons you come across, or else you will either get almost nothing out of them or end up dying due to the darkness. Time doesn't move when you're standing still doing nothing, so you can plan out everything. You also have to be very wary of the enemies the game throws at you. If you're not careful and don't take control of the battle, you'll end up finding yourself in a lot of trouble as they are quite strong. Look for various Weapons and Armors you can find because they will most likely be upgrades to your starting equipment. Eventually at 400km the Demon Lord will confront you for a final battle, he has barriers and a lot of HP. Throw everything you can at him, and eventually reinforcements will come to help you. Once you defeat him, you will see the credits, and beat the game...well sort of. See after the end of every run, whether it be due to death or completion, the game will score you on how well you did and you will receive Hero Points. You can use these Hero Points to expand your dimensional vault (A vault where you can store your treasures to use in other runs), unlock new perks and classes etc. This gives the game a ton of replay value as you have to complete the game multiple times to unlock everything. There are some problems I do have with the game, unfortunately. For starters it's quite clunky where you have to manually aim your attacks at enemies and you have to look in the menu to select an ability/item, and your movement speed is quite slow. Fortunately I hear the Plus version which I haven't played yet fixes all of those issues and and adds more content as well. I give the game an 8/10.

reviewText:
tl;dr- Seriously. You like JRPGs? Buy this game. You like persistant unlockables? Buy this game. You like random levels? Buy this game. This is one of my favorite games out there. Its fun to sit and play for 15 mins - or 4 hours straight.

Also - be happy knowing you're supporting 16-bit style WITHOUT USING RPGMaker. This game runs its own engine.
That in and of itself its worth it.

___________________________________________

At first glance, One Way Heroics looks like it was made on RPGMaker. It wasn't. Its a completely custom engine, from someone in Japan.

And, boy is it unique. Seriously. Yes, its an RPG. Yes, it is done in 16 bit style. But that is about the only thing that makes it anything like the RPGs back then.

The description on the store page really doesn't do it justice. It explains the base game. But it doesn't explain how incredibly addicting it is to go just one more run".

reviewText:
I've never posted a review of this game until now only because it's hard to find words to sum up how great it is without dragging the review on and on.

Here's what you need to know.
One Way Heroics is a relatively simple take on a lot of RPG elements woven into a roguelike fantasy. The system for gear statistics is pretty straightforward, as is the story-telling, as is leveling up. There are no skill trees or any choice of what stat you level up, but I promise you it won't matter.
That being said, the simplicity is nice. It allows you to play the game casually without taking away that constant strive some players have for better gear or the perfect run".

The combat is also quite simple. You have a basic attack you will use most of the time
date: as well as a few abilities learned from leveling or NPC's. It's quick
recommended: with you likely not spending more than 5 seconds on most enemies besides bosses. It keeps the game moving
hoursPlayed: which is nice because in a roguelike its important not to drag things out. This also allows you to keep the game short if that's what you want. Personally my average session is maybe 2 hours long
voteText: but if you insist on going as far as 2000km (which isn't neccessary to win)
helpfulPercent: it's a bit closer to 4 or 5 hours. Optional saves make those long games far less daunting.\n\nAs I said
votesHelpful: this game can work for casual players
votesTotal: but it does not leave the more dedicated players with nothing to do. 170 hours as I'm writing this review and there is still more to do. The game has a few interesting objectives woven into it to DRASTICALLY increase replay value
votesFunny: such as daily campaigns that change up the rules of the procedurally generated worlds you play in

This helps you to continue your quest for the absolute best gear by allowing you to keep enchanting gear instead of losing everything at the end of a playthrough. But it's not at all essential for beating the game if that's too easy for you ;)\n\nAs for the "One Way Heroics Plus" expansion (without going into detail)

reviewText:
You see, this game is like this...

You're an adventurer who managed to get past all of the horrible monsters in the beginning, and now you've gotten pretty strong and used to travelling.  Most monsters are a breeze and nothing seems challenging at all.

One day, you casually walk up to a dragon... just another day... and you notice too late that it's actually a red star boss dragon.  After one or two casual swings, you realized you carelessly placed yourself in a situation that you cannot escape.  Death is inevitable...

All of those hours you spent arduously preparing materials, training your blade, and gathering new OP weapons along the way... all gone... in all but a blink of an eye.

That's this game.

reviewText:
Being on sale this week for under a Dollar, I can't not recommend this to anyone who is looking for a light, but challenging look at the roguelike genre.

This game has surprised me many time with how it creates an equally challenging and fun experience while at the same time throwing many of the cumberrsome features of the genre overboard. The imperative of moving forward constantly creates an engaging pressure and forces you to make some interesting choices. The ability to leave some of your plunder to use for your next attempt is also fun without making it too easy.

If the graphics don't turn you off, you'd be a fool not to buy this on sale.

reviewText:
A game that thrives purely on its innovative gameplay.

Games like this are part of the reason why I love what indie games bring to the industry. While AAA developers stick to doing what they know will make money (sequel after sequel, FPSs, etc.), indie developers are more often willing to take risks on new ideas. Sure, you still get plenty of repetition out of the indie scene (side scrolling platformers, RPG Maker RPGs, roguelike elements, retro visuals, zombies, etc.) but I think that their overall percentage of innovative games brought to market is higher. Oddly enough, One Way Heroics features all the examples I listed in parentheses for repetition except for platforming, yet it still goes down as an innovative game in my book.

In order for you to be successful in One Way Heroics, every action you take requires that you be mindful of the ever encroaching darkness on the left side of the screen. It's such a simple concept and yet it has such a profound effect on the entirety of the game. I particularly appreciated how it forced a fast pace to the game (an extremely uncommon trait in RPGs) and demanded strategic thinking. Both of these play into a relatively harsh learning curve. My first attempt ended very early on yet I was quickly able to restart and learn from my mistakes. This isn't an exceedingly deep game so the learning curve relaxes after the first few hours. That said, between the 8 classes, a variety of perks you can choose from, and 4 difficulty levels, there are enough new things to try to keep your interest.

It's when you look outside of the gameplay that One Way Heroics comes up short. Its visuals, while not offensively bad, are very generic and bland. The music is a little better but equally generic. I'm still not entirely sure what to make of the story. It's odd because so much of it is worked into the game like an optional sidequest or rare, chance encounter. There were several moments that I enjoyed but the terrible English translation, silly anime character tropes, and high degree of difficulty in even accessing the story put a major damper on this aspect of the game. Despite 33 hours played I only ever encountered one of five NPC characters that you can have join your party and hear their story. The only reasons I can think of to have that level of rarity are a misguided attempt to elongate replayability or an MMO inspired reward for dedicated players. This is an excellent point to lead into my summary: One Way Heroics has a solid gameplay concept at its foundation but is surrounded by otherwise amateurish game design.

reviewText:
60% of the people who played this game probably hated it, but that's only because they didnt pay attention to what was happening. It's not frustating or boring, you just didnt pay attention.

You're dropped in a world  with no tutorial and no context, but once you do understand what you're supposed to do and how the game works, you'll se yourself playing a very VERY fun and interesting game.


There are lots of classes, lots of ways to play it, lots of bosses (!), there's even a way to befriend the boss and get him into your party, like what the hell that is amazing. I still didnt beat the game because ♥♥♥♥ this ♥♥♥♥ is hard, but its so fun i cant stop playing it.

Great game, great music, _GREAT_ price, HELLA ADDICTIVE, and the best thing, in my opinion, its a totally different game when you actually understand what is going on and what you're supposed to do. Also a gigantic plot twist in the end. Look foward to that.

reviewText:
when i first saw this game i thought that it was just a normal rpg with the twist of time preassure, and though this didn not seem so appealing i thought i might as well give it a try.

This game is such an inspiration for the rougelike genre.

for those who haven't looked up a review or anything about the game, the game has something called a dimensional vault where you can store a number of items whenever you die with a charachter. After your first attempt and death you are awarded with hero point and you can use these to buy mor dimensional vault slots and perks that you can use for the next attempt. Becuase of this every playthrough becomes valuable as you have to try you best every time to get good stuff and even though you may fail at beating the boss at that atempt the stuff you gathered can be stored in the dimensional vault and be withrawn at the start of the next game.

The game itself can be a little bit disappointing when you walk around and see a house or dungeon way too many steps away and you see it disappearing in the shadow every step you take, but be sure that there's going to be way more epic loot ahead. And if you are really obssesed with entering precisly that house you can reload the same world with the next charachter if you want to do so.

Personally i find the Pirate class to be the best one. Yeah he may have negative charisma making the villagers hate his face, but after adding 2 charisma+ perks everything is fine. Be aware that you have to unlock him though but it is way worth it.

anyway a great game and seems like something i will come back to now and then whenever i have hard time finding a game to play in my steam library containing 74 games....

reviewText:
When I first saw the game One Way Heroics it looked like something that could fill my spare time.
I decided to give it a shot for 3 bucks and this game blew me away.

This might sound like i am giving this game more credit than needed, but this has quickly turned into one of my favorite games to this date.
Of course the game has some flaws, but the good points of this game make it all. Let me give you a summary

This 2D Rogue-like RPG puts you in a world where the end is on it's way, and it is close! Every step that you make, every action that you do, will cause the end to draw closer and closer.
With dungeons, towns, npcs, monsters, holy items and companions spread all over the place, it quickly becomes a game where you have to think how much you can risk for opening that one chest that might give you a great item.

The first time you will complete the game will be in about your first hour of play ( getting to the end isn't that hard on the easiest difficulty) but with daily challenges, increased difficulty maps, secret endings (that i won't spoil) and a ton of classes to complete the game with. You will find yourself a new challenge almost every single day.

The game plays good, has controller support, has a good learning curve, and it makes you feel like a real hero when you accomplish something.

The cons?
Well if you don't like dying a lot, then this is not the game for you. One mistake or wrong decision can get you trapped and sometimes the game will be unfair to you.
Sometimes you will see the game paused with the message loading map" which is a slight setback in pace.
Classes are a little bit unbalanced (in my opinion this only adds more challenge for those willing to take the risk)
Maybe if you are really looking for a complex story in a game this might be a let down. (You are the hero
recommended:
thats about it)
But that is right about it for the Cons.

In short
hoursPlayed: while I only have 9 hours currently into the game
voteText: it feels like it has been minutes.\nIf you are looking for a cheap game that is worth the price
helpfulPercent: and that will consume your time like there is no tomorrow
votesHelpful: you will not be disappointed with One Way Heroics."

reviewText:
What a cute little game. So far the fun I have had in it has been well worth the small price tag. It is a fun and very replayable rogue like with forced side scrolling of the map. Let the darkness touch you and you will be consumed. Aside from the adorable classic rpg graphics
There are really nice features like:

-exchange levels of experience to gain main attribute boosts.
-Classes with more to unlock either by points or meeting the small requirement.
-Many weapons and armors to pick up or buy from vendors in game.
-Fun and yet very simple combat that should be pretty much common for most rpg/action rpg players.
-Perks that you can assign to you character to give them a little more oomph out the gate.
-Good soundtrack.
-Accessable gameplay that also really plays well on a x-box/ps3 controller.
-A vault you can expand to hold a few items from previous adventures that are made available to all your future runs.
-Random generated worlds

The game is great fun and easy to pick up for a short time and put down if need be. I do reccomend!

reviewText: Fun and unique interpretation of the Japanese RPG game type. On paper, the concept sounds forced and confusing, but the game plays intuitively after only a few lives. Most importantly, there is a great design sense that unifies the game as a whole. Each class encourages its own gameplay style, and character customization, through an unlock system, is flexible without being overwhelming. An inter-game treasure chest, like that in Shiren / Mystery Dungeon, allows players not used to roguelikes accumulate treasure without being able to horde it. Well worth the price: a game that is rewarding whether you invest hours into it or simply play it as a coffee-break roguelike.

One Way Heroics is a refreshingly unique spin on a classic genre. This game has countless hours of playtime and hardly any diminishing returns over time. The gameplay is technically turn based, but as long as you are moving it doesn't feel that way. Several classes and perks as well as the ability to slowly upgrade each consecutive character provides for a really unique, enjoyable experience. At $3.49, this game is a steal!

reviewText:
Good challenging game, best one I've ever played. And I hate challenging games, but this one is great! 9.5/10.  Here are pros and cons.

Pros:

- Great game, great balancing.

- Level system is nice.

- The stamina and stuff gives is a nice addition.

- I've never seen another RPG game like this, so thats great! Making a new idea is always nice!

- Whatever else I think is nice.

Cons:

- Lack of multiplayer, it would make the game a bit better in my option, give it that and you get my 10/10.

- Co-op would be cool too.

- Lack of classes, so far i've only found 5. I dont know how many there are, but still

- It should be completely new. They should make new classes that no one has ever seen, that'd be nice. There are the basics like Archer, Swordfighter/Warrior. Sure, all RPGs have that, but this one would be better without, because this game is a one of a kind, I dont think any other RPG game like this could top it. I have a few new class ideas in mind, like the Warage. It'd use a combination of wands, spellbooks and swords and shields. I think that'd be nice. This game should have stuff like that. Also, you can use my idea if you want.

- Finally, not much in the game itself. It gets repeatitive and boring really fast. Adding like Daily Challenges, Missions you could do like Go 500 meters in 20 seconds" or something would be great. Also adding something like a Christmas mode at the appropriate time each year
recommended: One Way Heroics is a great buy. It could use some more updates and things

reviewText: I got this game in the Humble Weeaboo Bundle that was running some time ago. You see, I was thinking hurr durr all those games have steam cards yay free games for me
date:
without actually considering if they would be fun. Frankly, I didn't expect any of them to be fun for longer than maybe half an hour.

And boy was I wrong.

>>SOUNDS AND MENUS AND PRACTICAL THINGS AND STUFF<<
When I started it up, I was greeted by the typical low-resolution menu screen that reminded me of some fond childhood memories with my mother. I would be playing on the couch with my gameboy, sound on, and after a while my mother would express her annoyence of this sound by imitating them with considerable volume. The sounds that engulfed me from my speakers when I started the game and saw the menu were the kind of sounds my mother would so fondly imitate to me with her loud loving voice.

Already almost teary-eyed I pushed the button on my controller - which works flawlessly with this game - to begin a new adventure.

Again, I saw a screen pop up in front of me which reminded me of home, of my mother. You see, I had to pick a name. And it so happens that my mother gave me my name. Hence, the memories. I felt the tears forming in my eyes again.

Aside from picking a name, I also had to choose a class and several perks. My choice for a class was somewhat limited at first, as I could only choose between two classes. This, however, did not discourage me. For it seemed to me that there would be many opportunities for unlockable characters. And who doesn't love unlockable characters? Gleeful at the prospect of being able to unlock things I picked a class at random, after which I proceeded to put all of my perk slots into extra strength. I would need it.

My heart leapt with excitement as I pushed the button that would initiate my adventure.

Another screen popped up: the final portal that would bring me to the different universe that I had been waiting for. All I had yet to do was choose which universe this would be. A multitude of opportunites (i.e. more or less 7) appeared before my eyes. And once more, childhood memories filled my mind. Of my mother, who would with a kind smile let me pick out my own clothes, and then get mad at me for not being able to pick anything good. Tears streaming from my eyes I went for the option that my mother would have chosen. The randomly generated world.

Another two pushes on the button (one for picking the world, a second one for picking the difficulty), and I finally arrived.

>>STORY<<
I was a hero, and I was greeted by noble king Victor. I was told of a terrible fate to befall these lands. Of darkness, doom, and despair. Of the impending danger that was right behind me. Quite literally. And I would be the one to stop its merciless assault on these former peaceful lands.

And so I embarked on my quest. The darkness ever licking at my heels. Again, quite literally.

I noticed that I also had gained help, in the form of an artificial fairy called Iris. She seemed to be there for all the questions I had, which were none as the blood of heroes had been passed down to me from my mother and hence I did not need any help. I blinked away a tear.

>>GAMEPLAY<<
I rushed through the lands, never resting. Every step I took seemed to take at least 5 minutes. And every step I took seemed to make the many monsters that roamed the lands take one step closer to me as well.

But I couldn't dally and dance with these fiends for long. With every action of mine the darkness crept closer. I knew that it would be my end should it reach me. So I continued, slashing through waves and waves of demons and monsters as fast as I could.

On the way, I met many different innocent people. They would offer me their help in exchange for the money I came across on my journey. It was a sad business they practiced. As much as I would have wanted to, there was no way I could save them from the darkness that was creeping towards us. Merely moments after I had finished bartering with them, I would hear their dying screams coming from behind me. From inside the darkness, where they met an untimely demise. With my money.

>>REPLAY VALUE<<
Ten minutes in my adventure I died. Like my mother.

Nah just kidding, she's still alive and kickin'.
I did die though.

But my death did not discourage me. I had learned from my failures and had become stronger through them. And I knew that I would keep standing up each time I fell down. And I would keep growing stronger, and stronger, and stronger.

And at last, I would make it. I would defeat the big evil boss, and peace would return the world!

But, would it be enough?

There were many other similar worlds. Like EWGHF, or QWUIHNAJ, or HHSJHEUI, or any other world that seemed to have gotten their names from some deity ramming his head on his keyboard several times.

Each and every single one of them needed the help of someone.

And that someone would be me. A hero.

A hero, like my mother.



;_;7

Nevertheless, the main part of the game is about the darkness, I think the darkness is pretty paced for what it does. Sure it can get behind your back when your swimming (unless you get the perk, yes i forgot to mention perks, and lots of them), or climbing through moutains, or getting trolled by some skeleton in a slim dungeon. Another cool little thing is the Dimensional Vault. When you die/beat the demon1656 you get to store items from your inventory and use them for the next adventure. You can choose not to and get recognition if you beat youknowwho xD.


If I would score it, I would give it a winRAR/winRAR

reviewText:
This is an extremely engaging game with simple mechanics that work well for it. If you are a fan of JRPGs or loot snagging in general, you'll have a great time.

Despite this being a procedurally generated roguelike game, it does manage to squeeze in some story and interesting characters. The unique bit is that, the generation is based off of whatever you want to type in. If you die in the dimension you entered if you want to revisit that dimension, the map generated will be the same (from what I've seen). This means that you can try to learn aspects of a specific dimension and plan around it.

Don't worry about the random generation screwing you over too hard either. On each character run you are always given 15 free turns that you can use in bundles of 3 whenever you want. So if you see a long stretch of unavoidable mountains, you could in theory use all 15 turns to pass them if it was really that bad/unavoidable.

The combat is simplistic, but deep enough that strategy actually matters since your positioning will often determine the outcome of a fight if more than one opponent is present. The game has a fair number of weapons and weapon types, some of which offer longer ranges and others which are really great at busting down terrain (Yes, you can break down walls of a house to talk to the people inside).

If you love optimization, NPC party building, pretending you actually have friends or are just looking for a fun game with a wonderful soundtrack, I'd spend the 83 cents to play this. I believe the regular asking price is $3, which is more than fair. Had I not only found this thanks to the steam sale, I would have gladly paid the $3.

reviewText: I gotta admit when I first bought this game for $.84 I really wasn't expecting much. Boy was I surprised when hours later I was striving to complete it with every class! This game has that certain appeal that just got inside my head, I love the simplicity/challenge of it (I know what I said)!\n\nWhether choosing to play it safe, or going for that new Force Power, One Way Heroics has become a game that I can't imagine not playing. With a price tag of under $5, and with the definite replayable factor, RPG fans of all types will enjoy this one!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's really interesting how a very simple concept can make something highly engrossing, and One Way Heroics is a good example of this in play. Take a very basic turn based movement and combat system, simplified stats and gear usage, and rather basic 'save the world' story as their parts, and this isn't anything new nor special by any degree, yet once you add in the ever moving 'Darkness', a mass of black that's always moving ahead, with or without you activly running away from it, and it suddenly becomes this odd pressured race of time and land management.

The main key point is whever you take an actions, yet it be attack or talking or even moving, the darkness moves a bit as well, devouring that part of the map with it making it no longger accessible. Suddenly you might be trying to rush towards a small city outpost hoping to sell your overload of loot, only to get there to watch the vender NPC's parish in that very second, having to now make a rush forward hoping another isn't too far off. It suddenly makes every little action you do feel 'importent' in the grand scale of things, and it really forces you to learn to look out for selective map alterations, or carry around Map Scrolls to ensure you don't miss anything vital. The NPC's you can recrute as well also have  rather small, but kinda interesting storylines, each one giving a bit more clear overarching idea of just what's going on, and perhaps a way to really 'save the world'. Not to ruin anything, but those who explore and read up will chances are find far more then this game first lets on.

On top of all of this, is a small, but nifty option of online interactions. It's nothing Dark Souls worthy of jolly co-op and the like, but it's more say little snapshots into other's current playing situations as they trek on the same world, able to share a small snipit of text, and be shown how they are status wise. Of course, on death, you can also share something much the same, and depending on where you died, your ghost might help someone else's journey along, dropping a random peice of loot you had at the moment. Beyond all of that, it's a nice, addicting, and simple game you can pick up for an hour or two, feel like you've made some progress, and seems to always have just ONE more little thing to show you even many hours after the fact.

reviewText: This light-hearted turn-based roguelike requires careful planning. Lots of replay as each playthrough gives you the opportunity to unlock additional abilities / classes, and you can stash loot into a shared vault even when you die. Similar to Cargo Commander, worlds are named by their seeds, so you can rank against friends by manually typing in the world name on a start (or similar.) It's, what, five dollars? Pick it up.

reviewText: Very clever use of scrolling. The game is based upon the idea that darkness is taking over the world so you have to constantly move forward or else you die. There are RPG elements that allows you to get stronger as well as a nice level of exploration. There a several classes you can unlock that slightly alters the gameplay.\nThis game is highly addicting. The replay value is amazing because every time, you can generate a new world to experience something new everytime.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
There's not much I can add that isn't on a dozen reviews already.  I got this game with a Humble Bundle, but it's easily worth the asking price and more.    You move through procedurally generated  worlds while trying not to get swallowed by the darkness (the left edge of the screen), picking up treasure and fighting monsters along the way.  With luck you will be strong enough to take on the demon lord.   But..there's more.  The demon lord can be a friend.  There are other people you can recruit, a number of unlockable classes, and a host of perks.  The real enemy is the darkness itself....

I'm averaging about half an hour per playthrough so far.  There's enough here to keep your mind busy - thinking up strategies, and running around looting things without running out of time - but the game's not going to bog down either.

As for replayability:  New dimensions, different classes, different endings?  This game has you covered.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: One of the most innovative RPG games I have ever played. When I saw the trailer I was worried that this was going to be another RPG maker game, but it is much more. A lot of love and care went into this game and it shows with the gameplay. This is one of those games that doesn't have a lot of mechanics, but it does what it does, and it does it very well. I don't reccomend playing with a controller, since the default controls are using the control stick to move. And since your character moves in four directions, it's quite difficult to position yourself. The gameplay is a sort of turn-based. The only way I can describe it is if you played games like Dungeons of Dreadmor where each time you move, the enemies (and darkness) move after you move. The graphics are also pretty good. I'm not sure if this game is made in RPG maker, but it does have similar graphics, like the mountains. I got this game as a part of the humble indie Japan bundle, and I've never been happier with my $15 I spent on it.

reviewText: For the price of the game it's definitely worth the money. You're able to jump in instantly and start playing. Controls and interface are all user friendly. Although some aspects are repetitive it's still very addicting. The use of different classes and different skills really adds some diversity into gameplay. Graphics might seem cheesy to some people but I think they fit perfectly with the game. Great game for short periods of play or even long periods.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. It's something that you can just pick up and play whenever you have a bit of free time. The replay value is infinite.

You control a character that is running away from the darkness that is engulfing the world. Your goal is to slay the Demon Lord to stop the darkness. Everything in between is a massive fight to survive and power up so that you can actually stand up to the Demon Lord. There are millions of dimensions with different map configurations. You can make the game very difficult if you want a challenge or very easy if you want some quick achievements.

Get this if you like old school RPG and RTS games. You won't regret it.

For you achievement hunters out there, this is a fairly easy game to 100%. I did it in 21.4 hours but you can easily do it in less as I messed around alot.

I have written a guide to help you unlock every achievement: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=298909961
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
One Way Heroics is an excellent game, let alone for the price.

I found it to have one of the smoothest learning curves for rogue-lites/likes. So you can make progress and beat it on an easy difficult consistently with a little practice. And if you can't you can either change your seed for a fresh run, OR practice your current seed and learn where the helpful locations/items are to progress further each time, or maybe store items for that leg up on the next run.

The classes all have a good variety in their bonuses, and while I found the swordsman and Hero easy to make overpowered there's plenty of success and strategy to be had with other classes. The perk system also helps you further optimize or offset weaknesses.

The game even accomdates further in that you can beat the demon lord in a quick 30 minute journey or invest in a 3-5 hour hike to the end of the world. You can even save and come back to journey after a break (or a series of poor decisions).

My rather nitpicky complaint is that the humor is a little immature/pervy, but overall harmless. And that I feel ultimately this game doesn't have quite the staying power of say Binding of Issac or FTL.  This is primarily due to the weapons all feeling very same-y, and there being little  mechanical skill in this game (i.e. if you take your time you should never input an unintended command). The music is also not quite as good as those other games.

That said this game scratches a similiar but different itch from those games and even if you only get 20 hours out of the game they will be 20 hours you won't regret, and stuff like daily events and the hardest difficulties could potentially get you many more past that.

reviewText:
For the price this game is asking for, there really isn't an excuse to just give One Way Heroics a shot.
It's interesting in the fact that the world to the left of you is being gobbled up by darkness, so you constantly have to move right.
Also its randomly generated, so when adventuring you can find weapons, items, armor, etc along your way.
If you ever find a level layout that you enjoyed, you can always respawn it with the game's seed function.
The art looks awesome with pixels.
And for the price of less than a dollar right now during the sale, but 3.50 later, its worth a shot to try.
and who knows? Maybe you'll enjoy it!

reviewText: This is truly wonderful game, easily better than some Triple A titles(in my opinion), and it is filled with many feels. It is generally simple, and at times it can be tense. The story itself is simple, as well with its gameplay and mechanics, but it is incredibly well done and thought out. At times it can be pretty easy, but can be extremely difficult. A great game for both; ones who want something simple and ones who look for a challenge. The generated worlds and rogue-like elements really add to it. Worth far more than it's standard price, and I bought it on the summer sale deal for $0.87.

reviewText:
This is one of the many extremely cheap games I got during the Summer Sales (2014).  I got it simply because I knew the trading cards would make up or at least almost make up for the 74 cents I spent.  I launched it, and was ready to let it sit and run for cards, but then, the music started.  The music was wonderful to listen to.  After sitting on the menu just listening to the music for about 30-/+ minutes, I decided I'd actually give the game a try.

I see a menu allowing me to choose my name, class, and additional perks.  Each of the characters has different standard perks, abilities, and gear.  Though it looks like you're going in extremely weak, you get random perks for leveling up and for exchanging levels with the Goddess statues that you find throughout the worlds.  If you choose the right combination of perks for a class, you can be very well set late-game.

The mechanics are simple; Z to attack, X to open the inventory menu, and C to open the grid view so you can aim without moving your character.  You progress to the right of the screen to escape the darkness that's consuming the land.  If you touch the left end of the screen, you die.  There's a boss to fight, and if you kill him, you win (though you will not kill him without leveled gear and good stats).  You can climb mountains and swim in water in exchange for turns and stamina.  You find items scattered about, there are merchants, dungeons, and random villages (of which usually have a person that allows you to save your progress).  It's pretty much a standard turn-based exploration RPG, but is very clever in which they execute certain aspects.

The first game I thought of while playing this game was one of my favorites for the GBA- Pokemon Mystery Dungeon: Red Rescue Team.  The moving mechanics, the menus, the navigation, and the soundtrack all are similar, and very well executed.  This game renewed the genre for me.

Why I Recommend It:

-The game has a very high replay value due to the randomly generated worlds and limitless perk combinations.
-The game is very cheap, and is well worth the money.
-The soundtrack alone is worth the cost of the game.  The game is almost just a bonus.
-It's very well set up, with little to no bugs (I have yet to find one)

Who I Recommend It To:

-People wanting to experience another classic RPG with a twist.
-People that enjoyed the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon series and games similar to it.
-People with limited funds.
-People that just want a game to play that is unlike many of the games here on Steam.

Who Should Avoid It?:

-People unwilling to pay the minute price.
-Idiots.

Final Thoughts:

I didn't think I'd invest as much time in it as I have.  This isn't one of those games you usually invest a lot of time in for straight playthrough (say, 5 hour+ sessions), though you can.  This is one of those games you would play for thirty minutes a day everyday.  Personally speaking, I'll certainly be coming back to it.

reviewText:
I managed to snag this game for one dollar, and even at it's worst it is a couple bucks. And quite frankly it feels like I'm robbing the developers. I've been pretty hooked the last few days on it and expect to push through until I get full completion.

It is a rogue-like game, meaning that it has perma death and randomly generated worlds. You make a character, you pick from some classes and perks, and you push that character as far as it can go. A darkness on the left side of the screen keeps you moving ever forward in your attempt to get as much gear and power before your inevitable death or the death of the endboss. When you die, you gain some points that you can use to unlock more bonuses to choose from and slowly amass a constant storage between characters so you can save some epic items.

There is no real multiplayer other than a Dark Souls-like feature where you encounter the ghosts of players on the same server that benefit you slightly and that you can compete with.

The sound is cute and retro, nothing astounding. The visuals are about Final Fantasy 1 quality but are pretty enough to get you through. The gameplay really hooks me. For some people, you will spend many hours through many characters striving to do better and unlock everything. For others, you'll play for an hour or two. And for the price you pay, you really can't go wrong.

reviewText:
Very fun, it's one of those games were you wanna keep playing, and it's such a drag that you have to stop :(. This is very great for the price, even when discounted. The price looks like it's already discounted! Worth more than 3.49. Also very good for trading card sellers like me, who sell every card they get (although I couldn't have bought this without a couple of vintage items on TF2). The most fun part is that you get to pick your own characters, random generated maps (I love rogue-likes' and random generated everything), and with online support, you can get help from ghosts of other dead people that have tried to beat demon1656 (See what i did there >:D sorry, just had to do it). Nevertheless, the main part of the game is about the darkness, I think the darkness is pretty paced for what it does. Sure it can get behind your back when your swimming (unless you get the perk, yes i forgot to mention perks, and lots of them), or climbing through moutains, or getting trolled by some skeleton in a slim dungeon. Another cool little thing is the Dimensional Vault. When you die/beat the demon1656 you get to store items from your inventory and use them for the next adventure. You can choose not to and get recognition if you beat youknowwho xD.


If I would score it, I would give it a winRAR/winRAR

reviewText: Looking at the game is one thing, but actually playing it is another.\n\nI love turn based RPGs, and dungeon crawler type games with Rougelike elements to it, loved playing the Mystery Dungeon: Shiren the Wanderer games, Torneko - The Last Hope - World of Dragon Warrior, Izuna: Legend of the Unemployed Ninja 1 & 2, and the Pokémon Mystery Dungeon games, after playing this game it gives me some of that satisfaction and a feeling of nostalgia, the gameplay is great, the music is beautifully set, the menu is well done especially being able to customize your hero player before you set off on your random generated adventure, you only start off with 2 classes to play with, after each playthrough by completing it or dying through you'll get points to unlock other perks and classes to help you strategize for your next playthrough  since there's also difficulties to choose from as well, oh did i forget to mention that the far left side of the map is trying to consume you and the whole world, yeah this game is great. :D

reviewText:
Pure genius.  One Way Heroics is probably one of the better indie games this year that you won't hear about.

If you enjoy generated games or the old school sprite RPG's, get this, get it now.

The game-play is pseudo-turn-based where every time the player performs an action, the game world will iterate as well.

Pros: Excellent replay value.
Nice sprite visuals
Fun, Simple gameplay: Run right, adventure, fight or flee from a large variety of monsters, search for supplies. Visit towns and talk to NPCS.
Do all of the above while impending doom is always advancing towards you.
Due to generated content, you never know what you'll encounter.  Each new adventure has its surprises.
Lots of secrets to uncover.
Works with gamepads other than the Xbox360 Controller.
Able to carry some equipment over to a new adventure.Cons: None.  Although you need to come into this game expecting to replay it repeatedly to really get anything out of it.  Not a traditional linear RPG at all.
One of my favorite indie games for 2014.

reviewText:
Even if I had paid full price for this, I would still recommend this game. Its a quick to play roguelike game that is easy to jump in to and play and can be difficult to master, although being that its a roguelike still means that there is an element to randomness so that even if you feel you have the hang of it you can be thrown a curve ball and knocked out.

In addition to the roguelike nature of it, there is some perma elements, such as unlocking new classes to be played in next playthroughs as well as a stash that allows you to store good items for next playthroughs.

Overall for the cost, whether you get it on sale or not, definitely a recommend and I definitely wish more games were as easy to jump into and have fun as this game.

reviewText:
So, I bought this game because it was cheap.
Was it worth it?
Of course it was. Why not check it out for a dirt cheap price?
It has a feel like The Binding of Isaac to me, without the random item rooms. Instead, you get sacks on floors.

While I experienced a crash after creating a character, I figured out that you can just go to options and disable online settings.
(crash fix right there for you folks.)

After a while, it felt like a clash of genres of games that I loved;
Perma death, (you can have a vault in which you put items from your last run in)
On my third or fourth run, I got the hang of it.
It felt a bit bland, but online might seem like fun.
The jist of the game is that you can only continue to go right, and after 400km you have to fight the final boss, who is obviously quite difficult.
Each time you die, you get Hero Points, which you can use to unlock classes, perks, and expand your vault to store items in in order to pass it on to your new character, like Rogue Legacy.
It seems like it'll hold me over for a good week in single player, but I can't wait for multiplayer to work for me.
