reviewText:
I have not in a long time played such a roguelike that captures all the difficulty and strategy of Shiren the Wanderer style games, and successfully marries it with unique quirks of its own. This title is one that I can say really brings a completely new feel to the roguelike genre.

More in line with newer roguelikes, it is an easy to pick up, hard to master game with the freedom to tackle it how you please. The side-scrolling aspect of it keeps you on your toes and constantly vigilant. You're forced to move a quick pace to outrun the darkness, but are still given the ability to search for loot at as much leisure that can be allowed. In a way, this really brings the right level of tension and speed to the game. Not to mention the music. It really caught me off guard and I found myself humming many of the songs.

In summation, if you're looking for a new game to add to your collection this should be a prime candidate. The playthroughs are quick, but extremely fun. At three dollars, saying this is a steal is an understatement.

reviewText: First things first, do you like Roguelikes? If so then this game is a very prospective find for your collection! It's a very perma death and turn based unforgiving type game but of course it has features that work around that kind of system, being able to bring items over from previous gameplays and also unlocking new classes and perks to make yourself stronger at the beginning. The pace it sets with the darkness constantly chasing you is very fresh as well because not only is it a roguelike game but it also has aspects of time management almost like Half Minute Hero, making gameplay have a much more frantic pace even though it's still turn based. Another thing that makes the game fun to play is the online features, it's always fun playing a game and knowing others are doing the same, the little pop in messages aren't disruptive at all and seeing how far other people are reaching and how many other people are failing is fun in it's own rights. Of course, it's got the sharing aspect from games like Minecraft and Starbound, you can share any of the worlds that have been generated by simply giving the world's code to friends and other people. All the worlds have their own little leaderboards too, with rankings and other things, you can even see how people went about their adventure. Also, you can actually get better at a world/dimension since it's layout never changes aside from random loot drops and events. Overall, while simplistic and a bit more on the hectic/rushed side, it's still pretty in depth, especially with the carryovers and whatnot, you can even grind items out to twink yourself up for the next run. As an ending note, don't expect to win early on unless you play on the easiest difficulty, losses are inevitable on this game as they are a part of it, take it in as it comes and build yourself up to become stronger to finally defeat the Demon Lord!

reviewText:
Okay, One Way Heroics is not a normal RPG, not by any means. Sure, there are the usual suspects, such as stats, leveling, items, monsters and even a final boss. But that is where the similarities end. Each game is a race against the clock where the encroaching darkness at the left of the screen advances while your heroic character must scramble right in search of experience, items, gold and helpful npc's.

Sound fun so far? It gets better, not only is the difficulty brutally hard and the classes vary in play style, but each world you play in is randomly determined at the start of a game. You can keep the names of these worlds and re-enter them to go back to the same world as before, yet even then the experiences are fresh enough to ensure replayability of the highest caliber.
Like in Rogue Legacy, death is not the end of your efforts. Choosing a new class, and storing items in the dimensional vault makes the next game a little less harrowing if you choose. You can use the Hero points, awarded at the end of the game to unlock more classes and perks.

That being said, I was not kidding when I mentioned the brutal difficulty. In addition to powerful enemies, you might not have the best equipment because merchants do not appear often and you might not have cash at hand then. Or they appear often, but sell basic articles. And if you find a legendary sword? Use it sparingly as all equipment has a lifebar of such, if it runs out they break. Unless you have awesome perks and have gained levels at a crazy rate you can't beat the Demon Lord naked and unarmed.

In conclusion, this game is truly one that gives great bang for so few bucks. So get it!

reviewText:
It's really interesting how a very simple concept can make something highly engrossing, and One Way Heroics is a good example of this in play. Take a very basic turn based movement and combat system, simplified stats and gear usage, and rather basic 'save the world' story as their parts, and this isn't anything new nor special by any degree, yet once you add in the ever moving 'Darkness', a mass of black that's always moving ahead, with or without you activly running away from it, and it suddenly becomes this odd pressured race of time and land management.

The main key point is whever you take an actions, yet it be attack or talking or even moving, the darkness moves a bit as well, devouring that part of the map with it making it no longger accessible. Suddenly you might be trying to rush towards a small city outpost hoping to sell your overload of loot, only to get there to watch the vender NPC's parish in that very second, having to now make a rush forward hoping another isn't too far off. It suddenly makes every little action you do feel 'importent' in the grand scale of things, and it really forces you to learn to look out for selective map alterations, or carry around Map Scrolls to ensure you don't miss anything vital. The NPC's you can recrute as well also have  rather small, but kinda interesting storylines, each one giving a bit more clear overarching idea of just what's going on, and perhaps a way to really 'save the world'. Not to ruin anything, but those who explore and read up will chances are find far more then this game first lets on.

On top of all of this, is a small, but nifty option of online interactions. It's nothing Dark Souls worthy of jolly co-op and the like, but it's more say little snapshots into other's current playing situations as they trek on the same world, able to share a small snipit of text, and be shown how they are status wise. Of course, on death, you can also share something much the same, and depending on where you died, your ghost might help someone else's journey along, dropping a random peice of loot you had at the moment. Beyond all of that, it's a nice, addicting, and simple game you can pick up for an hour or two, feel like you've made some progress, and seems to always have just ONE more little thing to show you even many hours after the fact.

reviewText:
One Way Heroics is a rogue-type constantly moving rpg. In short, it's a brilliant game for a lover of rpgs who also happens to be incredibly ADHD. I picked it up for in incredibly low price (less than a dollar!) and got way more than my money's worth. I would pay more for this game, if only I wasn't a cheap sonofagun.

The game starts with a basic intro, then throws you right into character making. Not many choices for now, but after the first run (and death) it becomes obvious that there are many more classes, perks, and items to unlock.

My first few runs were less than perfect. I found one chest out of thirty and didn't even make it 100km. I tried to esacpe from monsters by going into the mountains. HINT: Don't do that.

But I was immediately hooked. I loved the looks, the AMAZING music, and I really wanted to beat the hell out of the enemies that were doing the same to me.

I'll be playing this game very often. I give it a 9/10.

reviewText:
I managed to snag this game for one dollar, and even at it's worst it is a couple bucks. And quite frankly it feels like I'm robbing the developers. I've been pretty hooked the last few days on it and expect to push through until I get full completion.

It is a rogue-like game, meaning that it has perma death and randomly generated worlds. You make a character, you pick from some classes and perks, and you push that character as far as it can go. A darkness on the left side of the screen keeps you moving ever forward in your attempt to get as much gear and power before your inevitable death or the death of the endboss. When you die, you gain some points that you can use to unlock more bonuses to choose from and slowly amass a constant storage between characters so you can save some epic items.

There is no real multiplayer other than a Dark Souls-like feature where you encounter the ghosts of players on the same server that benefit you slightly and that you can compete with.

The sound is cute and retro, nothing astounding. The visuals are about Final Fantasy 1 quality but are pretty enough to get you through. The gameplay really hooks me. For some people, you will spend many hours through many characters striving to do better and unlock everything. For others, you'll play for an hour or two. And for the price you pay, you really can't go wrong.

reviewText: I got this game in the Humble Weeaboo Bundle that was running some time ago. You see, I was thinking hurr durr all those games have steam cards yay free games for me
date:
without actually considering if they would be fun. Frankly, I didn't expect any of them to be fun for longer than maybe half an hour.

And boy was I wrong.

>>SOUNDS AND MENUS AND PRACTICAL THINGS AND STUFF<<
When I started it up, I was greeted by the typical low-resolution menu screen that reminded me of some fond childhood memories with my mother. I would be playing on the couch with my gameboy, sound on, and after a while my mother would express her annoyence of this sound by imitating them with considerable volume. The sounds that engulfed me from my speakers when I started the game and saw the menu were the kind of sounds my mother would so fondly imitate to me with her loud loving voice.

Already almost teary-eyed I pushed the button on my controller - which works flawlessly with this game - to begin a new adventure.

Again, I saw a screen pop up in front of me which reminded me of home, of my mother. You see, I had to pick a name. And it so happens that my mother gave me my name. Hence, the memories. I felt the tears forming in my eyes again.

Aside from picking a name, I also had to choose a class and several perks. My choice for a class was somewhat limited at first, as I could only choose between two classes. This, however, did not discourage me. For it seemed to me that there would be many opportunities for unlockable characters. And who doesn't love unlockable characters? Gleeful at the prospect of being able to unlock things I picked a class at random, after which I proceeded to put all of my perk slots into extra strength. I would need it.

My heart leapt with excitement as I pushed the button that would initiate my adventure.

Another screen popped up: the final portal that would bring me to the different universe that I had been waiting for. All I had yet to do was choose which universe this would be. A multitude of opportunites (i.e. more or less 7) appeared before my eyes. And once more, childhood memories filled my mind. Of my mother, who would with a kind smile let me pick out my own clothes, and then get mad at me for not being able to pick anything good. Tears streaming from my eyes I went for the option that my mother would have chosen. The randomly generated world.

Another two pushes on the button (one for picking the world, a second one for picking the difficulty), and I finally arrived.

>>STORY<<
I was a hero, and I was greeted by noble king Victor. I was told of a terrible fate to befall these lands. Of darkness, doom, and despair. Of the impending danger that was right behind me. Quite literally. And I would be the one to stop its merciless assault on these former peaceful lands.

And so I embarked on my quest. The darkness ever licking at my heels. Again, quite literally.

I noticed that I also had gained help, in the form of an artificial fairy called Iris. She seemed to be there for all the questions I had, which were none as the blood of heroes had been passed down to me from my mother and hence I did not need any help. I blinked away a tear.

>>GAMEPLAY<<
I rushed through the lands, never resting. Every step I took seemed to take at least 5 minutes. And every step I took seemed to make the many monsters that roamed the lands take one step closer to me as well.

But I couldn't dally and dance with these fiends for long. With every action of mine the darkness crept closer. I knew that it would be my end should it reach me. So I continued, slashing through waves and waves of demons and monsters as fast as I could.

On the way, I met many different innocent people. They would offer me their help in exchange for the money I came across on my journey. It was a sad business they practiced. As much as I would have wanted to, there was no way I could save them from the darkness that was creeping towards us. Merely moments after I had finished bartering with them, I would hear their dying screams coming from behind me. From inside the darkness, where they met an untimely demise. With my money.

>>REPLAY VALUE<<
Ten minutes in my adventure I died. Like my mother.

Nah just kidding, she's still alive and kickin'.
I did die though.

But my death did not discourage me. I had learned from my failures and had become stronger through them. And I knew that I would keep standing up each time I fell down. And I would keep growing stronger, and stronger, and stronger.

And at last, I would make it. I would defeat the big evil boss, and peace would return the world!

But, would it be enough?

There were many other similar worlds. Like EWGHF, or QWUIHNAJ, or HHSJHEUI, or any other world that seemed to have gotten their names from some deity ramming his head on his keyboard several times.

Each and every single one of them needed the help of someone.

And that someone would be me. A hero.

A hero, like my mother.



;_;7

reviewText:
Okay, One Way Heroics is not a normal RPG, not by any means. Sure, there are the usual suspects, such as stats, leveling, items, monsters and even a final boss. But that is where the similarities end. Each game is a race against the clock where the encroaching darkness at the left of the screen advances while your heroic character must scramble right in search of experience, items, gold and helpful npc's.

Sound fun so far? It gets better, not only is the difficulty brutally hard and the classes vary in play style, but each world you play in is randomly determined at the start of a game. You can keep the names of these worlds and re-enter them to go back to the same world as before, yet even then the experiences are fresh enough to ensure replayability of the highest caliber.
Like in Rogue Legacy, death is not the end of your efforts. Choosing a new class, and storing items in the dimensional vault makes the next game a little less harrowing if you choose. You can use the Hero points, awarded at the end of the game to unlock more classes and perks.

That being said, I was not kidding when I mentioned the brutal difficulty. In addition to powerful enemies, you might not have the best equipment because merchants do not appear often and you might not have cash at hand then. Or they appear often, but sell basic articles. And if you find a legendary sword? Use it sparingly as all equipment has a lifebar of such, if it runs out they break. Unless you have awesome perks and have gained levels at a crazy rate you can't beat the Demon Lord naked and unarmed.

In conclusion, this game is truly one that gives great bang for so few bucks. So get it!

reviewText:
A cute game that satisfied all my expectations!
But~ expect a rigid story and you'll be disappointed as the story is rogue-like as is the gameplay. Although this also means that there is room to tell your own tale in the adventures that will be had.
The difficulty is hard from the get go, and you'll take risks along the way to level up- Being too careful will hinder your level from rising, but barging in to a fight expecting to win will usually not end well!
So you will have to take use of the turn-based system to plan a strategy. But! Is there enough time for a rigid strategy as the world is swallowed up behind you? (each turn) -That is for you to adapt to as you discover this ever changing landscape.

-Good-
About the turn-based system, keep in mind it goes as fast as you want it to. You can run just as in any overview-2d game. But when you stop, everything else stops. This makes it both exhilarating but calming at the same time to me!
Want to compete with other players? You can play the very same world (not simultaneously) and check leaderboards for whom performed the best in a variety of aspects such as leveling and treasure hunting etc-.
And lest forget the character art, they have a charming manga-illustration kind of look which takes me back Final Fantasy IV.

-Cons-

Not a variety of tile texture- Since you'll find yourself writing a story to complement the lack of complete story, a larger variety of landscapes to inspire our minds would be nice. Also weather and lightning effects would be welcome.

No simultaneous multiplayer (just leaderboards). If the creators got an idea for how to implement multiplayer but still hold this fast-paced turn-based system, i could potentially see how that'd make for a sequel with great promise! But that's just me. (^^)

Okay! Get to the adventure! :3

reviewText:
It has some bugs, and it may be a little hard to get into at first, but once you understand the concept, it is really fun!

The price is unbelievable, especially on sale. I'm not usually the kind of person who looks in their recommendations and randomly buys a game, but this is my genre, and less than one euro? Bought.

The gameplay itself kinda reminds me of Pokemon Mystery Dungeon, but with a lot more RPG elements and... well... Darkness. Apart from that, it also has other unique elements like the dimensional vault or some of the abilities.

I'm pretty sure I have never seen an ability before which makes my stats OP in exchange for my clothing. Artstyle is awesome too.

And if you complain about missing content: Look at the price again. Or buy the DLC, like I did, which also makes the game easier too play with improved controls.

I love it.

reviewText: Before purchasing this game, I was sceptical of the darkness mechanic mostly because I don't like feeling rushed in a game. What caught my attention to the game was the mult-world system, where there are infinite world seeds to add infinite possibility to the game, which also meant a lot of replay value. Secondly, the graphics and classes reminded me of my old favorites, the Final Fantasy games. After buying the game and DLC on a good whim, and trying it out for the first time, I immediately loved it. The encroaching darness actually made it a lot of fun because it added a sense of hurry and a feeling of loss when you couldn't reach that item or town in time, but it also wasn't too fast as to ruin the focus of the gameplay so I don't mind the rush because it still gives ample opportunity to do what you want while constaly reminding you to keep moving. Lastly, the dimentional storage system made it so that playing it again and again wasn't such a drag for unlocking new things because you can store and take items from the storage throughout multiple playthroughs making it a bit easier than doing it from scratch (although its a fun challenge playing hard difficulties without using the stoage).\n\nSo as for final thoughts on the game; I definitely recommend it to anyone who likes old school RPG's with a twist. Also if you're looking for a game with great replay value, I'd say this game is up there with 'Binding of Isaac: Rebrith/Afterbirth' for a fraction of the price. It has plenty to unlock, along with a fair amount of items to use to your advantage. 9.5/10 Definately would support this game if more DLC's came out for it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I seriously enjoy this game. One of my favorite aspects of a randomly generated world is the fact that you're not going to see everything the first play through... Or the second play through... Or even the twenty-second! I still have not figured out how to recruit other party members during the journey, but I'm fine with that because I've been so preoccupied with discovering all the other things you can do with different classes.

Speaking of classes, I normally hate class systems in an RPG. When you have to devote to one for the entire game and you're not even sure if it's your favorite because you haven't got to try the others yet. But in One Way Heroics, many runs are fairly short, so you can try every class that you like. Get a feel for all of them. Then play the one you feel like playing based on your mood. It's kind of like a fighter game in that aspect; you pick a character based on the kind of match you expect to have.

Another great thing about the classes in One Way Heroics is the fact that they all have something unique and interesting to bring to the table. Each has a special skills, and each has regular skills that they perform better or with a bonus. It's balanced pretty well and it makes picking a favorite for your style of play easy.

The variety of items is the last good point I'd like to touch on. One thing I almost always start out with is increased inventory ability, because I love picking up as many items as I can and using them effectively. One Way Heroics exhibits great balance between character stats and the necessity for equipment. You can make your character strong, sure, but if you don't find a rare and powerful weapon or some really good armor, you're going to be running from the demon lord many times before you can hope to fight him.

The one down side to this game I'll mention is the character design. The artwork is a little sloppy looking, though charming in it's own way, and the character dialog, while funny at first, is a little lacking in terms of variety. Well. during gameplay anyway--Dialog is actually pretty good during cut scenes, as I am hit with something new almost every new game and end game. Finally characters feel a little flat. Even though the after story of you and the fairy continuing your journey after the world is saved is rather touching, it feels awkward because I don't really feel connected to the characters. They're too generic, but then, maybe that was intended.

All in all, great game. 9/10

(This is my first review, so I haven't developed any kind of coherent style.)

reviewText:
For a game that regularly goes on sale for less than a dollar, it's absolutely amazing, the dlc for the game, while making the game harder, adds so much convenience to the interface. Now for the breakdown

Music
The music is never really downbeat, though there are times when it's calmed down.
It tends to pick up to a rousing adventure theme when combat really begins to happen
The music in towns is really calming, to the point that I've just sat in towns listening to the music playing

I tend to reccomend listening to the music of any game prior to purchase though, and there's an awesome playlist on youtube containing all of the music from the game.

Interface
The interface in the base game is kind of unintuitive, with the keys being used as follows: R T W A S D Ctrl Shift

There might have been more, but either never needed them, or they just didn't come up.

The intro menu here is really simple, but the opportunity to rerun a map you like just because you remember its seed is awesome, but there's not much that's all that interesting in the intro menu.

The in-game menus are interesting, but I do have just one issue in that you can use" a bomb
date: by which I mean it will just explode on you. I don't know why this is an option but I accidently use the bomb instead of throwing it more often than I'd like to admit. But beyond the occasional issue with that
recommended: the menus are easy to understand

reviewText: This game is a sidescroller that doesn't wait for you. Stuck in a mountain range? This game doesn't care. The darkness that is the edge of the screen will consume you. The enemies will all stab you for fun and if you attack animals, hippies will chase you to the ends of the Earth. If you decide to fight back against said hippies, you now have a bounty and can no longer visit towns unless you want to get shanked. This game is quite difficult and very fun. I'll also mention that it is currently about $.80. I would have happily paid at least ten times that price.

reviewText: I bougth this game on a steam sale thinking for the price even if I played a little of it it wouldn't be a dissapointment. I was actully surpirised on how much I liked it and how many hours I sank into it. It is nice in the fact it doesn't do any hand holding (none besides keep moving right). So there was lots of trial and errors (dying) with charaters class (which you can unlock more as you progress) until you find your rythm. Each user will have a class they are just better at and a class that they rather not use (its all dependant on your playing style) and there are particular monsters that are bigger pains in the butts. It really is your game: want to kill citizen for gold you can, want to collect tons of treasure, sure, or just run away from everything (including the dark lord). You unlock more story as you continue playing and playing with different charaters classes. Its not the most complicated game out there but it can keep you playing for quite some time.

reviewText: It's a nice little roguelike with a twist. Said twist works out surprisingly well. It's not very expensive and it's pretty enjoyable. The one real downside is the balance seems to be a bit wonky, with holy weapons being perhaps too crucial to victory. The Dimensional Vault is a nice concept, which definitely helps some of the problems stemming from the randomness. The soundtrack is also a nice touch. All in all, it's worth the low cost, but bear in mind that it can be a bit repetitive after awhile.\n\nHave not tried the new expansion yet.

reviewText:
Let's get the important things out of the way right here at the start:

Is One Way Heroics a good game? Yes.
Is it fun? Yes.
Should you buy it? Yes, especially when on sale.
Is the OWH+ DLC worth it? Yes, every steam penny you spend on it.

Now for the unnecessarily long analysis portion:

One Way Heroics is a Roguelike with large amounts of Turn-Based RPG elements. Your character grows stronger as they defeat enemies, you can equip a variety of different weapons, there are multiple character classes, and there are even quests in the game which require recruiting certain characters or speaking with a specific person (OWH+ has quests to unlock extra character classes and a quest to return a little girl to her father).

Some other mechanics the game runs on include:

- Everything moves on a grid
- You have a stamina bar that allows you to climb mountains, swim in water, and use special attacks
- You also have an energy meter which is refilled by eating food, it also provides energy for force attacks
- Every recruitable character has affinity that goes up as you travel with them or do specific things on the way such as eat a specific kind of food or kill enemies
- The recruitable characters can also be levelled up
- Weapons can be given extra attributes via scrolls or other such objects
- Most items have weight (arrows and gemstones don't) and if you exceed the weight limit, you can't move
- You can unlock various perks that help you along the way
- You can find goddess statues throughout the world which give you special boosts for the cost of levels
- The Awakening ability, which allows you to take five consecutive actions without anything else moving
- The Dimensional Vault which lets you store items from a run and take them out again for a different run
- Your weapons and armor will break after a certain number of hits, given or recieved

Mechanics specific to OWH+

- Food can go bad as time goes on
- You level up upon reaching a new area
- You can add extra parts to the starting castle with Dimensional Gold Coins you find in each run, you can also place special NPCs in these extra parts
- Extra perks that make the game harder but greatly improve your rank and score
- Tons of extra items that aren't in the regular version

The biggest and most important game mechanic however, is the darkness. The darkness is always on the left side of the screen, and if you get swallowed by it, you die. Every time you do something, be it moving, attacking, equipping an item, or even talking to someone, the darkness moves forward. This means that ever action has to count, and you have to really think of possible risk vs. reward of doing specific things. Because if you go into a dungeon and can't get back out in time, you will be consumed and that'll be it. You can use the Awakening ability to get away, but it only has five uses per run, and the world goes on for a long way (10,000 km if I recall correctly).

Overall, a really good experience, and one I highly recommend.

reviewText:
One Way Heroics is a fun and easy to understand approach to RPG rogue-likes with features to help the player extend his own gameplay from a single playthrough.

We choose from a variety of classes with pickable perks and go on a random adventure.
Encountered by enemies and time itself, we wander across endless open plains and underneath mountain ranges, find dungeons with lots of danger and treasure, find cities to sell our useless stuff to NPCs and head further east.
This gameplay routine might sound boring and stale but is actuallly a really fun activity the more you play.

The charm lies in the different classes and the different approach of each class.
You can level up" your class globally in a way and earn Hero points at the end of each game (regardless of victory or death) and put these points to good use by buying additional perks or classes and more slots of a globally shared item storage that all your future characters have access to. Give yourself a headstart if you start to struggle.

My current playtime/bought-price ratio: 4hours > 0.75$
Rogue-like Quarter-diminisher: 4hours*0.25
End-result: 1 > 0.75$

tl;tr
This game is worth its sale price so do buy it if you find it for under a dollar.
For this game will redeem itself by the playtime it offers.

Tiny tips:
>press the "c" button to focus your attack panel because you can actually hit all of your eight adjacent panels
>use it for a planned sideway walk because pressing two arrow buttons simultaneous sounds pretty rough if one wrong move can end your game if you accidentally find yourself in a predicament.
>Infact
date: you can play this game entirely with just your arrow buttons and the "Y"

reviewText:
Very hard to get used to the controls for some reason, but once you do the game is amazing, i suggest playing it while watching a walk-through for it so that you can better understand the world you've entered. The game itself isn't inherently hard, but you have so little to work with that it takes getting used to. Warning to new players to stay away from Golems, they have set spawn locations per world and they are nasty with or without an axe (which does more damage to them).

Characters can be unlocked with points rewarded for your progress after each death or by completeing a certain feat. You can use these points to get a vault and add space to said vault. The Vault NPC is in the set spawn for each character. I recommend always keeping a Key of Seals in the Vault if you manage to come across one. Keys of Seals are used on Temples and can give you Holy Artifacts. My first holy artifact was an Axe that crushed everything before me. By the time it had worn down i found another temple and another key of seals, and got a Holy Spear and Holy Chest Armor. Made it the last 80 km to the Demon Loard and killed him with no struggle.

I've only gotten 2.8 hrs of playtime in the time of this review, but i could easily put 200 hours into it. It's cheap for it's value of entertainment, and if you end up in a poor spawn you can always just continue again.

More tips
-Always buy from a Chef When/If you reach a town. They seem pricey but in actuality they are cheap and extremely valuable.
-This game is about Trade-offs, you may end up choosing things that are detrimental to the world you spawn on.
-More expensive is not always better, especially when you do not have a high enough Item-Appraisal to know what you are buying.
-Randomly Generated worlds always have their problems, the largest map wrecker in this game is large mountain walls that you have to climb. They take a great deal of turns to climb and eat your stamina, if you find yourself having to climb mountains frequently you will die, and you may want to explore a different route or a new world entirely.
-Chests in the water are also death-traps but if you can manage it, they may offer useful loot.
-Teleportation Pills will save you from Bandits, Bears, or Golems.
-Axes will destroy walls and chests with ease for better dungeon navigation.
-Bows and Lances will help you kill your enemies from a distance, very beginner friendly weapons, unless you have no arrows.

Negatives about this game -

The loss of your character after completeing the game is without a doubt a loss, but the ability to save his gear makes up for it, despite the fact it is battered and will probably have to be repaired despite my deep loathing of the brittle debuff.

reviewText: Before purchasing this game, I was sceptical of the darkness mechanic mostly because I don't like feeling rushed in a game. What caught my attention to the game was the mult-world system, where there are infinite world seeds to add infinite possibility to the game, which also meant a lot of replay value. Secondly, the graphics and classes reminded me of my old favorites, the Final Fantasy games. After buying the game and DLC on a good whim, and trying it out for the first time, I immediately loved it. The encroaching darness actually made it a lot of fun because it added a sense of hurry and a feeling of loss when you couldn't reach that item or town in time, but it also wasn't too fast as to ruin the focus of the gameplay so I don't mind the rush because it still gives ample opportunity to do what you want while constaly reminding you to keep moving. Lastly, the dimentional storage system made it so that playing it again and again wasn't such a drag for unlocking new things because you can store and take items from the storage throughout multiple playthroughs making it a bit easier than doing it from scratch (although its a fun challenge playing hard difficulties without using the stoage).\n\nSo as for final thoughts on the game; I definitely recommend it to anyone who likes old school RPG's with a twist. Also if you're looking for a game with great replay value, I'd say this game is up there with 'Binding of Isaac: Rebrith/Afterbirth' for a fraction of the price. It has plenty to unlock, along with a fair amount of items to use to your advantage. 9.5/10 Definately would support this game if more DLC's came out for it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Highly recommended. Besides being a unique procedurally-generated RPG with an appealing soundtrack, this game has another worthwhile distinction that isn't frequently mentioned in positive reviews: One Way Heroics is conducive to playing in short bursts, or for hours at a time. On a low difficulty, you can clear the game in half an hour, provided you have some idea of what you're doing. Higher difficulties -- assuming you don't blunder about and lose right away -- can offer hours-long campaigns. I appreciate that kind of versatility in a game, and One Way Heroics does it better than most.

reviewText:
This is a good little Semi/Rogue like RPG it's doesn't cost a lot and despite being a small game there is actually a lot of stuff to do like unlock the many different classes, perks and find all the hidden endings and find all the possible special partners the thing than surprise me the most of how deep the story of the game is. (I mean for such a little game anyway)

You can play on many different kind of world you can even input your own code to create a random world for yourself or enter one of your friend or other people codes to get certain partners easier there is also a *Multiverse* world where you can see what the other people playing the game right now are doing top left corner even if you cannot actually see them. (It actually add a lot of fun to know that ROXXOR just died killed by a small harmless puppy...)

reviewText: Looking at the game is one thing, but actually playing it is another.\n\nI love turn based RPGs, and dungeon crawler type games with Rougelike elements to it, loved playing the Mystery Dungeon: Shiren the Wanderer games, Torneko - The Last Hope - World of Dragon Warrior, Izuna: Legend of the Unemployed Ninja 1 & 2, and the Pokémon Mystery Dungeon games, after playing this game it gives me some of that satisfaction and a feeling of nostalgia, the gameplay is great, the music is beautifully set, the menu is well done especially being able to customize your hero player before you set off on your random generated adventure, you only start off with 2 classes to play with, after each playthrough by completing it or dying through you'll get points to unlock other perks and classes to help you strategize for your next playthrough  since there's also difficulties to choose from as well, oh did i forget to mention that the far left side of the map is trying to consume you and the whole world, yeah this game is great. :D

reviewText:
Well... How to say that. It has been quite a few months that I rarely got into a game and played it more than 2 hours, except some like Borderlands 2, Minecraft, and some little other games.. And well, this game is a rare jewel in gaming industry, which I know I'll play a lot before stopping.

First, I got it as a present, so I didn't have to spend anything on it, but damn that was an awesome gift. As for the game itself, I first thought it would be a really repetitive thing where you always do the same thing with no fun... And it's an awesome game with lots of fun.

The first thing that hit me is that I will always want to play more. I'm not a fan of games where you have a limited amount of time to do something, but the darkness push you to go further in the game, and gives an incredible adrenaline boost.

Second thing is that I'm a great fan of Roleplay and such, and this game is just like urging my Roleplaying soul to put myself into my character. It just gives so many possibilities, you cannot avoid this game if you like Roleplaying as much as I do.

So, I guess I'll make kind of a summary:

Pros:
+ Very fun game, never gets boring
+ Graphics pretty decent
+ Just one more turn"-kind of game
+ One playthrough is not that long until you find a save point/die
date:
so you can play this when you're bored and have little time
+ My Roleplaying feti... I mean soul is pleased
+ It's quite funny sometimes as well
+ Your personal fairy that will ask you to bath because you stink
+ Great durability

Cons:
- Little character creation
recommended: only two appareances for each class and perks... Although the classes are all fun.\n- The randomly created worlds can go from "you're fukken' lucky" to "lol ur doomd m8". I never screamed as much when I had to pass through a snow biome
voteText: then volcanic

and then snow again.
- Really frustating when you lose your game because you lacked one turn after achieving more than you ever did.

Conclusion:

Would I advice you to buy this game? Depends. If you don't want to play a game where you do quite the same thing over and over again

reviewText:
Have you ever gotten a game for sale price and after playing it, you feel like you'd have been satisfied with the value even if you paid full price? For me, One Way Heroics is that, except I'd feel happy paying more than sale price.

One Way Heroics is a rouge-like game kinda like a Mystery Dungeon game, except you're not stuck in a dungeon and have a randomly generated world to explore. Except with one twist: There's Darkness to the left. And it endlessly creeps up on you. And if you fall in it, you're dead! So you're stuck going to the right. And there's monsters out there, too, so remain on guard! Of course, there's helpful stuff out there, too!

One Way Heroics is kinda tough at first, but it gets easier as you go along, unlock classes, and generally get an idea of what to do. And it's alright if you mess up after you got some cool item, because after you die or clear you game, you're allowed to put items into the Dimensional Vault, to use them on another run. You've got limited space, though, so until you're heroic enough to expand it, watch how you use it!

I had a lot of fun with this game, and I only spent 87 cents on it! So it's a definite recommendation from me.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A unique Japanese roguelike that plays like classic Mystery Dungeon mixed with the oft-touted auto scroll mechanic that makes players think even more on their feet as they battle monsters (and hunger).  This is probably one of the only roguelike games with a progression system that fits perfectly with the game as a whole, with many runs only lasting about an hour, and the most you can get are unlockables to change your starting character or to save equipment. Whatever writing is there is usually light-hearted and sometimes witty, even in such a depressing world where everyone behind you DIES. I also love the world generation system where you can replay the same seed over and over again and almost play it like a normal RPG.\n\nThe Plus version is pretty much necessary to fully enjoy this game, but I think the low price and hours of fun you'll get is worth it. I'm not even done with it myself!

reviewText:
I got this game on a sale, long time ago, for a dumb and extremely low price, something like half an euro, or even less. To tell you the truth, for such a price, I was expecting something horrible, dreadful, like an 8-bit Ride to Hell. Did I got surprised? Yeah! Buuuuuuut as usual, let me explain the BAD things the game has first, so we can take them out of the way:

The game is kind of short. Of course, for such a price, you can understand it, so it's not that big of a deal. Besides, this is a Rogue-like game, and rogue-like games are usually short, but change in every playthrough, this is no different from the standard on that regard.

The other thing that I did not like at all, is the lack of multiplayer. This game had such extreme potential for a Coop experience, but instead you can play the same randomly generated world at the same time as one of your friends, to see who goes further...INSTEAD OF PLAYING TOGETHER, AND HAVING FUN! I was indeed dissapointed by that, by looking at the captures of some friends that got the game, and by looking at the pictures and videos of the Steam-Store, I was expecting to play at least with one friend in a journey to save the world by punching demons on their d#cks.  You know, the usual.

Now, let's talk about the GOOD stuff, pretty much everything else. As I said, it's a Rogue-Like. At the start of the playthrough you select the kind of character you desire to control, and special skills for you: You want to be fast? You want to be strong? You want to use magic? You want to start with a companion? You want to start with insane amoutns of gold? It's your choice, and it's indeed well made. I really did enjoy starting in different ways, and testing different strategies.

The game pretty much goes like this: The world is being taken out by some sort of Dark Sonic Boom" (Damn Obama

reviewText: One Way is a multiplayer RTS, it kind of reminds me like Starcraft II, but before the big update. In this game you play as a small, low quality character with low stats, and get better by killing things, the aim is to get strong enough to take the enemies base before he takes yours. In the campaign mode you're tasked to destroy the Government by progressively building up your rep through street racing, and (Spoilers) taking the crown off of the president when you long distance race for pinks.\n\nAll in all I really enjoyed playing this game, and I would recommend it to my friends, I will update this when I have tried the Co-op mode :D

reviewText: This game is brutal no matter what difficulty you pick, in best possible way as a rogue-like. It has a VERY surprising amount of depth for a game that is by default played on a resolution of about a smart phone (what you see in the screenshots is what you get, and full-screening it does not help its prettiness!). reviewText:
One Way Heroics:
8/10

+ Very Challenging, i recommend to do Easy (Walk in the park) if you don't know how to play, or if you're just bad in Gaming.
+ Amazing RPG/Turn Based Game.
+ Really worth these 3 euros.
- Very Simple Story. World is in danger -> go save the world -> kill monsters -> kill boss -> you win
- Short Game if you know how to play.

I really recommend this game if you are a fan of RPG/ Turn based games, and if you're not a fan of that, then i still recommend to check it out.
it's really worth the 3 euros.
Played it for ~1-2 hour and finished the game on my Third Attempt after that i wrote this, was kinda sad it was pretty easy to finish the game.
But yea, i did Easy mode, and all the other difficulties are really hard to beat.

I approve this game, and im glad it's in my Library :)

reviewText: I really didn't expect much going into this game - it was cheap, and I didn't even attempt to play it for a few months after buying it.  After giving it a shot, I can say it's a breath of fresh air in terms of innovating on some ancient gameplay ideas.  The design of the game keeps you moving, so it's fast-paced and very replayable.  The controller support is a great touch.  There are quite a few levels of difficulty though I haven't experienced any of the more advanced stuff myself yet.  If you're looking for a game that's worth a few bucks, this is a nice addition to your library.

reviewText: I have played a decent amount of this game, and I think it is time to write a review. One Way Heroics may not seem much as it is an RPG game, but once you get into it, you will fall in love with it. The first thing you may notice of the game is the music. The music practically sets it apart from other RPG or any other games in general. The music is the emotion of the game. The story is pretty interesting too, and the whole time you have to run away from the looming darkness. That is where the name comes from, since you can only go in one way or direction. The last thing I have to say about this amazing game is: The difficulty. This game is not easy at all, you will die many times. Sure, you may rage quit, but this game will draw you back. It is different everytime you play it.\n\nTo sum all things up, get the game. The money is worth it, and you will enjoy playing it.

reviewText: Very addicting, cute and hilarious. Some online connectivity but very limited. When the game said it had online features I thought it meant you could have a party for a single instance at least but the closest you get is a leaderboard and ghosts of the dead players. Hopefully this can be expanded a little at least. Otherwise, I've thoroughly enjoyed playing hours at a time of this game, the replay value is worth it. And hopefully the upcoming DLC will not be more then twice the base price of the game....

reviewText: I have played a decent amount of this game, and I think it is time to write a review. One Way Heroics may not seem much as it is an RPG game, but once you get into it, you will fall in love with it. The first thing you may notice of the game is the music. The music practically sets it apart from other RPG or any other games in general. The music is the emotion of the game. The story is pretty interesting too, and the whole time you have to run away from the looming darkness. That is where the name comes from, since you can only go in one way or direction. The last thing I have to say about this amazing game is: The difficulty. This game is not easy at all, you will die many times. Sure, you may rage quit, but this game will draw you back. It is different everytime you play it.\n\nTo sum all things up, get the game. The money is worth it, and you will enjoy playing it.

First
column24: for the achievement-seekers out there

column33: but possibly not the best reason

column35: OWH is a genuine rogue-like that is
column36: albeit simple and on the easy side

reviewText: A hidden gem. Got it for $1 thinking I'd put an hour in and be done, but then I found myself addicted for a while. Challenging, but rarely ever furstrating, and always fun. I'm not a fan of roguelikes; losing all my progress with nothing to show for it isn't my bag. However this game managed to get me hooked on it despite loss after loss because of the minor progression system that unlocks new content after every playthrough.\n\nA deep, fun experience that just so happens to be $1 every major sale. Give it a go, you've got nothing to lose.

reviewText:
TLDR:  Only buy this game if you get it WITH the expansion, and preferably on sale.  The reason I don't recommend it is because One Way Heroics is still an incomplete game, with the expansion and all.

The review:

After 70 hours playtime, I can't recommend One Way Heroics.  Without the expansion (One Way Heroics Plus, $6.49), this game is borderline unplayable.  The expansion brings in much needed UI updates, gameplay tweaks, more items and more characters.  And a ton of bug fixes.

Problem is, most of that stuff should have been patched in to the base game.  Or, more realistically, put in to the game before it ever released.  Especially since, even with all that, it still feels like a beta version.  Very late in the beta process, but still not quite ready for release.  Somewhere in the polishing phase.  Bugs are still being squashed to this day, and I experienced plenty in my time with the game.

Once you take all the things from OWH+, and subtract them out since they should have been included in the main game prior to release, you're left with just the new classes and the castle expansions.  And they aren't worth $6.49 by themselves.  The classes are easy to gloss over, and none of the castle expansions have a huge impact on your game.  You can easily do without both.

With a bit of a shallow story, one that was also poorly translated, the gameplay is what keeps you coming back.  And it's (almost) all there... so long as you make sure to pick up OWH+ as well.

reviewText:
One way heroics is a great rogue-like turn-based quasi-tactical rpg.
It's hard to label this game as any one specific catagory, but it's ideal is apparent.

This game is all about strategy, and uses a grid-based platform.
If you are a fan of fire emblem style gameplay, you may like this game.

The second element is more of a rough and tumble type of turn-based rogue-like battle system.
First you choose your action, then all other actions occur after your action, then time moves foreward and stops when it comes back to your turn. It's a very simple, yet complex system as there are a multitude of effects to change the style that you play. (examples: combos, criticals, ranged, meditation, throwables, etc etc)



Another huge aspect, which I believe carries this game to a better aspect, is it's music.
While the volume isn't always properly adjusted for some of the areas, the music is still great for every single area/theme in the game.
also I swear I heard guile's theme...


In addition to to having great music, the effort they put into the smaller details in the game, such as character interaction and ending sequences, goes to show how much they actually cared for the game. This is something more developers need to do.


I would give this game a solid 9/10.
-1 point for including hippy tree huggers.

The system is kept rather simple, and games necessarily have a relatively short duration even if you win them by killing the demon lord at the end. (I managed to win on my 3rd try, which took about an hour.)\n\nMultiple playthroughs are worthwhile because there are various classes and perks to be unlocked. Additionally you have a dimensional vault" that you can use to store up items from your previous attempt to use in your next one. So while your character isnt all that persistent
date: your profile is.\n\nI bought the game on sale for $1
recommended: and it was one of the best $1 purchases I've made here."

reviewText:
A fun, but repetitive game, that will quickly grow old.

The game is essentially a roguelike 'lite', as there actually isn't much randomization when you get down to it. A handful of terrain types, a handful of dungeon layouts, a handful of enemy types. After a few playthroughs, you'll have seen everything in the game, so it's only a question of what order you'll encounter them.

Many of the perks are of miniscule use at best, such as improving your swimming skill. The classes generally aren't too different from each other in practice, outside of their own gimmick. The Force User, for example, can learn spells at any time by exchanging levels. But most of the spells aren't worth the cost, so you'll find yourself using your basic attack spell while saving up experience. Since most skills have a significant cost restriction, you'll find yourself using basic attacks and relying on position for most of the game, rather than unique skills.

That being said, for $4, you're getting your money's worth. A few hours of fun, maybe more if you really want to stretch the challenge, and it is very fun for those few hours. It might be a game that you enjoy for an afternoon, then forget about for a few months, only to come back and enjoy it again. Maybe it'll be a game you only enjoy for a day, even if you never play it again. All in all, worth checking out if it appeals to you, but don't expect it to be exceptionally memorable.

reviewText:
The game is fun but at some parts tricky too.
it is an RPG rogue like game.
There is sidescrolling but not in your favor.
every step, every move, every action that you do the left side of the screen will be getting closer to you.
If it has reached you, you are dead. So make sure you are not inside of a building when that happends lol.

You have to kill enemies to get  experience and leveling up and finding loot to make your character stronger.
You get points at the end of the level which will help you on the next run. (once you have spend it ofcourse)

So basically you are running away from the left side, fighting, and till you have reached the marker point, you will have to fight the boss itself.

Game is very good in music,  graphics is nice too. Gameplay is fun!

8/10

Let's Try Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0uEWVKeroIo
